questions.text: Following a stab wound to the right side of his neck, a 23-year-old man is having trouble communicating. The tip of the tongue is deviated to the right in the tongue protrusion test. In this patient, which of the following nerve is the SINGLE most likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
The hypoglossal nerve is the twelfth cranial nerve XII, and innervates muscles of the tongue. The following are the common causes of this nerve injury:

  • Lower motor neuron lesions – Polio, syringomyelia
  • Stroke
  • Bulbar Palsy
  • Neck trauma
  • Surgery – Carotid endarterectomy

Symptoms often show deviation of the tongue towards the paralyzed side when it is stuck out. This is because of the weaker genioglossal muscle.

Other lesions:

Facial nerve lesion leads to facial weakness and loss of taste sensation of anterior two third of tongue.

Vagus nerve lesion results in weak cough, vocal cord paralysis with dysphonia. There is also parasympathetic loss of innervation to respiratory, gastrointestinal and cardiovascular systems.

Trigeminal nerve lesion presents with loss of gag reflex, loss of taste sensation from posterior third of the tongue, loss of general sensation from posterior pharynx, tonsils and soft palate

questions.text: After 30 minutes of sitting cross-legged, a 35-year-old male was unable to dorsiflex his left foot and lost sensation in the web space between the big and second toes. What is the ONE anatomical structure that is most likely to be affected
questions.solution:
Motor functions

  • The deep peroneal nerve innervates the muscles in the anterior compartment of the leg which are responsible for dorsiflexion of the foot at the ankle joint.

Sensory functions

  • The deep peroneal nerve innervates the webbed space of skin between the great toe (hallux) and the second toe

Clinical relevance The deep peroneal nerve can become entrapped or compressed during its course through the anterior compartment of the leg, and so a patient loses the ability to dorsiflex the foot. With unopposed plantar flexion, their foot drops.

There are two main reasons why the deep fibular nerve could be compressed.

  • The first is that the anterior leg muscles have been excessively used and so are compressing the nerve with the anterior compartment. The patient will experience pain in the anterior leg.
  • The other common cause is tight-fitting shoes, compressing the nerve beneath the extensor retinaculum. This commonly occurs with wearing tight ski boots (referred to as ski boot syndrome). The patient will experience pain in the dorsum of the foot

questions.text: After a sudden fall on his right knee, a 12-year-old child appears with a severely swollen knee. The pain is confined to the area below the kneecap. Which anatomical structure is the most likely to be harmed?
questions.solution:
Prepatellar bursa

The prepatellar bursa is a frontal bursa of the knee joint. It is a superficial bursa with a thin synovial lining located between the skin and the patella.

Prepatellar bursitis classically occurred in housmaids, hence the nickname ‘housemaid’s knee’. It is commonly seen in people who knee such as plumbers. Friction caused by repeated kneeling can cause it. It is a common cause of swelling and pain over the anterior inferior patella.

Symptoms

  • Redness
  • Inability to flex the knee
  • Pain and swelling is localized over site of bursa (e.g. below patella) Rest usually relieves symptom

questions.text: In Refsum’s disease, a oxidation is impaired and phytanic acid is not oxidized. Which strategy helps in treatment of this disease?

choices.text: Restricting dairy products and green leefy vegetables
Taking diet rich in essential amino acids

questions.solution:
Refsum's disease is a rare but severe neurological disorder characterized by cerebral ataxia and peripheral neuropathy. The patients of this disease accumulate large quantities of an unusual fatty acid, phytanic acid. It is derived from phytol, a constituent of chlorophyll. Hence it is found mostly in plant foods. However, it is also present in milk lipids and animal fats. Phytanic acid cannot undergo β-oxidation due to the presence of a methyl group on carbon-3. This fatty acid undergoes initial α-oxidation (to remove α-carbon as carbon dioxide) and this is followed by β-oxidation.

Refsum's disease is caused by a defect in the a-oxidation due to the deficiency of the enzyme phytanic acid α-oxidase. The result is that phytanic acid cannot be converted to a compound that can be degraded by β-oxidation. The patients should not consume diets containing chlorophyll (i.e., green leafy vegetables).

questions.text: Which of the following decrease the release of prolactin from anterior pituitary?
questions.solution:
Prolactin hormone stimulates milk production in breast; inhibits ovulation in females and spermatogenesis in males by inhibiting GnRH synthesis and release. For most of the anterior pituitary hormones, it is the releasing hormones that are important, but for prolactin, a hypothalamic inhibitory hormone probably exerts more control. Prolactin inhibitory hormone (PIH) by hypothalamus is a dopamine (catecholamine) which causes inhibition of prolactin secretion. Thus metoclopramide which is a dopamine antagonist, increases the production of prolactin by blocking the receptors of dopamine on prolactin producing cells of anterior pituitary.

Thyroid releasing hormone from hypothalamus increases the release of prolactin.

Also estrogens released in pregnancy promote the release of prolactin from pituitary and support lactation and mammary gland development.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman arrives at Accident and Emergency with a serious cut on the palm of her hand and the back of her wrist. Her ring finger's distal phalanx is incapable of being extended. What is the MOST LIKELY AFFECTED STRUCTURE?

The flexor digiti minimi is a hypothenar muscle that causes flexion of the 5th digit (the little finger) at the metacarpophalangeal joint.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man has a pelvic chondrosarcoma removed, and the obturator nerve is sacrificed in the process. As a result, which of the following muscles is the least likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
Sartorius is supplied by the femoral nerve. In approximately 20% of the population, pectineus is supplied by the accessory obturator nerve. Adductor magnus has a composite supply from the obturator and sciatic nerves.

Obturator nerve

The obturator nerve arises from L2, L3 and L4 by branches from the ventral divisions of each of these nerve roots. L3 forms the main contribution and the second lumbar branch is occasionally absent. These branches unite in the substance of psoas major, descending vertically in its posterior part to emerge from its medial border at the lateral margin of the sacrum. It then crosses the sacroiliac joint to enter the lesser pelvis, it descends on obturator internus to enter the obturator groove. In the lesser pelvis the nerve lies lateral to the internal iliac vessels and ureter, and is joined by the obturator vessels lateral to the ovary or ductus deferens.

Supplies

  • Medial compartment of thigh
  • Muscles supplied: external obturator, adductor longus, adductor brevis, adductor magnus (not the lower part-sciatic nerve), gracilis
  • The cutaneous branch is often absent. When present, it passes between gracilis and adductor longus near the middle part of the thigh, and supplies the skin and fascia of the distal two thirds of the medial aspect.

Obturator canal

  • Connects the pelvis and thigh: contains the obturator artery, vein, nerve which divides into anterior and posterior branches.

Muscle Nerve supply (part of muscle)
Trapezius Spinal accessory nerve (motor)
Ventral rami of C3, C4 (proprioception)
Digastric Trigeminal nerve (anterior belly)
Facial nerve (posterior belly)
Pectoralis major Medial pectoral nerve
Lateral pectoral nerve
Subscapularis Upper subscapular nerve
Lower subscapular nerve
Brachialis Musculocutaneous nerve (motor)
Radial nerve (proprioceptive)
Flexor digitorum profundus Median nerve (lateral half)
Ulnar nerve (medial half)
Opponens pollicis Median nerve (superficial part)
Ulnar nerve (deep part)
llio-psoas Direct branches of the anterior rami of L1-L3 (psoas major)
Femoral nerve (iliacus)
Pectineus Femoral nerve (anterior fibers)
Obturator nerve (posterior fibers)
Biceps femoris Tibial part of sciatic nerve (long head)
Common peroneal nerve (short head)
Adductor magnus Tibial part of sciatic nerve (ischial part)
Obturator nerve (adductor part)

questions.text: Which of the following is a false statement?

choices.text: Inspiratory capacity refers to the maximal volume of air that could be inspired after completing tidal expiration
Closing volume refers to the lung volume above residual volume at which the airways in the lower, dependent part of the lungs begin to close off

questions.solution:
INSPIRATORY CAPACITY (TV + IRV)

  • Total volume of air that can be inspired

FUNCTIONAL RESIDUAL CAPACITY (ERV+RV)

  • Amount of air that remains in lung at the end quiet expiration

VITAL CAPACITY (TV+IRV+ERV)

  • Amount of air that maximally exhale out after 1st maximal inspiration

TOTAL LUNG CAPACITY (TV+IRV+ERV+RV)

  • with maximum inspiration, Lungs are at TLC
  • with maximum Expiration, Lungs are at RV
  • With quiet Expiration, Lungs are at FRC

CLOSING VOLUME

  • That volume just above the RV (Starting from TLC) at which airways near the base of lungs begin to close → Base of Lungs closes First
  • With aging, closing volume approaches FRC d/t airway remodeling

questions.text: Which pathway entirely occurs in the cytoplasm of the cell?
questions.solution:
• All Anabolic Pathways occur in Cytoplasm
  • All Catabolic Pathways occur in Mitochondria

Pathways which occur in both Mitochondria and Cytoplasm

  1. Gluconeogenesis
  2. Urea cycle
  3. Haem synthesis

Whenever a pathway occurs in both, it starts in mitochondria and finishes in cytoplasm

TCA, ETC (Vital Pathways occur in MITOCHONDRIA and do not depend on fed or fasting state)

Some more examples of pathways that occur in different compartments are-

Pathway Nature Compartment

Fatty acid synthesis Anabolic Cytoplasm

questions.text: Which of the following statement is NOT true?

choices.text: A Reynolds number > 3000 indicates a turbulent flow
Arterioles offer the greatest resistance to the blood flow
Capillaries are referred to as capacitance vessels

questions.solution:
Veins are referred to as capacitance vessels. More than half the volume of blood (54%) is presents in venous compartment.

Reynolds number determines the tendency of turbulence.

  • < 2000 = Laminar flow
  • >3000 = Turbulent flow
  • 2000-3000= Transition flow

Viscosity depends mostly on hematocrit. Viscosity increases in hyperproteinemic states (eg multiple myeloma), polycythemia. Viscosity decreases in anemia.

Arterioles offer greater resistance to blood flow and has maximum effect on blood pressure (pressure head drops maximally). Greatest drop of pressure occurs also occurs at the arteriolar Segment (Resistance vessel).

questions.text: What is the pathophysiology of graves disease?

choices.text: Destruction of the thyroid by lymphocytes
Antibodies stimulating TSH receptors on thyroid
Focal patches of hyperfunctioning follicular cells distended with colloid working independently of TSH

questions.solution: In grave’s disease, the immunoglobulin antibodies bind with the same membrane receptors that bind TSH. They induce continual activation of the cAMP system of the cells, with resultant development of hyperthyroidism. These antibodies are called thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin and are designated TSI. They have a prolonged stimulating effect on the thyroid gland, lasting for as long as 12 hours, in contrast to a little over 1 hour for TSH. The high level of thyroid hormone secretion caused by TSI in turn suppresses anterior pituitary formation of TSH. These auto-antibodies also have receptors on dermal fibroblasts causing pretibial myxedema and on orbital fibroblasts causing Graves orbitopathy which causes exophthalmas due to deposition of fat & fluid in retrobulbar space degeneration of EOM (extra ocular muscles).

questions.text: You're seeing a medical student examine a patient's neurological condition. You decide to quiz them on their neuroanatomy because they forget to perform the reflexes. Which of the following pairs of reflexes and innervating spinal nerves is correct?
questions.solution:
REFLEX ACTION INNERVATION
Anal (and wink) reflex Contraction of external and sphincter muscle on stroking the skin around the anus S2-S4
Ankle reflex The Achilles tendon is sruck causing plantar flexion of the foot S1 & S2 Sciatic nerve
Knee (patella) reflex The patellar ligament is struck causing contraction of the quadriceps muscle L3 & L4 Femoral nerve
Biceps reflex The biceps brachii tendon is struck causing flexion at the elbow C5 & C6 Musculocutaneous nerve
Brachioradialis (supinator reflex) Triceps reflex The brachioradialis is struck causing wrist extension with radial deviation The triceps brachii tendon is struck causing extension C6 & C7 Radial nerve C6 & C7 Radial nerve

Damage to the associated nerves can also lead to diminished reflexes.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man presented with syncope, dyspnea and chest pain with exertion over a period of 6 months. Upon workup, he has been diagnosed with aortic stenosis. What is the most expected finding on cardiac examination in this patient?

choices.text: Holosystolic murmur that increases with leg raise
Crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur that increases with passive leg raise
Late systolic crescendo murmur with midsystolic click that decreases with leg raise
“Blowing” early diastolic decrescendo murmur that decreases with inspiration

questions.solution:
The patient in this case has been diagnosed with aortic stenosis and the cardiac murmur most expected is a crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur. A soft S2 (ejection click may be present).

Mostly the right-sided murmurs increase with inspiration and left-sided murmurs decrease with inspiration. Also maneuver like leg raise that increase preload increase the intensity of most murmurs as they increase the flow through the stenotic or regurgitant valve (except in mitral valve prolapse and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy).

Thus aortic stenosis murmur decreases with inspiration and increases with leg raise

Holosystolic murmur that increases with leg raise describes murmur of mitral or tricuspid regurgitation.

Late systolic crescendo murmur with midsystolic click that decreases with leg raise describes murmur of mitral valve prolapse.

“Blowing” early diastolic decrescendo murmur that decreases with inspiration describes murmur of aortic regurgitation.

MANEUVER CARDIOVASCULAR CHANGES MURMURS THAT INCREASE WITH MANEUVER MURMURS THAT DECREASE WITH MANEUVER
Standing Valsalva (strain phase) ↓preload (↓ LV volume) MVP ( ↓LV volume) with earlier midsystolic clickHCM (↓ LV volume) Most murmurs (↓ flow through stenotic or regurgitant valve)
Passive leg raise ↑ preload (↑ LV volume)
Squatting ↑preload, afterload (↑ LV volume) Most murmurs (↑ flow through stenotic or regurgitant valve) MVP (↑ LV volume) with later midsystolic click HCM ( ↑LV volume)
Hand grip Most other left-sided murmurs (AR, MR, VSD) AS ( ↓transaortic valve pressuregradient) HCM ( ↑LV volume)
Inspiration ↑↑ afterload →↑ reverse flow across aortic valve ( volume) Most right-sided murmurs Most left-sided murmurs

questions.text:
Match the following-





Gastrin
Cholecystokinin
Motilin
Ghrelin
Intrinsic Factor




B12 absorption
Increases appetite
Increases pancreatic secretion
Migrating motor complexes
Zollinger Ellison Syndrome
questions.solution:
Gastrin is released by G cells in antrum of stomach and duodenum. It increases gastric acid production and gastric motility. Gastrin secretion is increased in chronic PPI use, in chronic atrophic gastritis (eg, H pylori) and in Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (gastrinoma).

I CELLS → ↓Gastric motility

Secrets CCK → ↑Intestinal motility

Stimulated by fat → Causes enzyme rich pancreatic

Breakdown products → Juice to be secreted

Bile flow from gall bladder (cholagogue)

Motilin is secreted by small intestine that strengthens the MMC (MIGRATING MOTOR COMPLEX) which are the house keeper of Intestine(similar in colon and has haustrations).Erythromycin binds with Motilin Receptors (Hence, used as prokinetic drug)

  • Ghrelin is secreted by stomach and functions to increase the appetite. It is significantly increased in Prader-Willi Syndrome.
  • Intrinsic Factor is released by parietal or oxyntic cells of stomach and is a vitamin B 12 binding protein which aids in B12 absorption from small intestine. Autoimmune destruction of parietal cells can lead to chronic gastritis and pernicious anemia.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a correct statement?

choices.text: Meissner corpuscles are large, myelinated fibres that quickly adapt and are part of our skin
Pacinian corpuscles are involved in sensing pressure
Merkel receptor is a slowly adapting receptor, thus with continued stimulus the receptor response stops
Free nerve endings sense temperature and pai

questions.solution:
• Receptor responds to stimulus briefly. With continued stimulus receptors response stops
  • ↓the unnecessary burden to cerebral cortex
  • When continuous stimulus is removed, receptors responds briefly
  • Meant to detect change in the environment

TYPES

  1. RAPIDLY ADAPTING/PHASICRECEPTORS
  2. PACINIAN CORPUSCLE
  3. Phasic receptor
  4. Mechano receptor Best suited for vibration

2. SLOWLY ADAPTINGRECEPTOR

  • MERKEL RECEPTOR
  • Helps in continuously sending the important sensory information

The Free nerve endings sense temperature and pain. Comprise of Aδ—fast, myelinated fibers and C fibres—slow, unmyelinated. They are present in all tissues except cartilage and eye lens; numerous in skin.

Meissner Corpuscles are large, myelinated fibres rapidly adapt and present on hairless skin. These sense the speed of application of touch eg flutter along the skin.

questions.text: At the level of the first lumbar vertebra (L1), which of the following is present?
questions.solution:
The first lumbar verebra is level with the anterior end of the ninth rib. This level is also called the important transpyloric plane, since the pylorus is at this level. Other important structures are also located at this level, they include; fundus of the gall bladder, coeliac trunk, superior mesenteric artery, termination of spinal cord, and hilum of kidneys.

The Transpyloric plane, also known as Addison’s Plane, is an upper transverse line, located halfway between the jugular notch and upper border of the pubic symphysis. The plane in most cases cuts through the pylorus of the stomach, the tips of the ninth costal cartilages and the lower border of the first lumbar vertebra.

questions.text: A 60 year old female is diagnosed with Cushing’s disease. Which of the following physiological features would NOT be appreciated in the patient?
questions.solution:
Cushing disease is characterized by hypercortisolism. Thus all the manifestations related to increase in cortisol could be appreciated in the patient.

CUSHING DISEASE

It can cause hyperglycemia, hypertension, osteoporosis, hirsutism. Screening tests include: Increased free cortisol on 24 -hr urinalysis, Increased late night salivary cortisol, and no suppression with overnight low-dose dexamethasone test. In cushing disease Serum ACTH is elevated and High-dose dexamethasone suppression test shows Adequate suppression

  • d/t fat breakdown & centripetal redistribution of Fat
  • Moon Face
  • Buffalo hump
  • Protuberant belly
  • Thin Limbs (lemon on matchstick appearance)
  • Striations over abdomen

Cortisol decreases osteoblast activity; therefore, it decreases bone formation and puts the patient at risk of osteoporosis.

questions.text: In which phase of myocardial action potential the calcium ions entry start?
questions.solution:
FAST RESPONSE TYPE

O : Rapid upstroke →by Fast Na+ channels (Tetradotoxin sensitive) 1

  1. Early repolarisation → by K+ exit
  2. Plateau phase
  3. Rapid Repolarization → by slow Ca2+ channels
  4. Resting membrane potential

PHASE2

  • By slow Ca2+ channels → slow inward movement of Ca2+ ( ECF Ca2+) → Causes electrical & contractile activity (Ca2+ Sparks)

In phase 2, Ca2+ entry starts through slow voltage-gated Ca2+ channels that balances the K+ efflux and hence the plateau is observed in phase 2. Calcium influx also triggers Ca2+ release from sarcoplasmic reticulum of myocytes and causes myocyte contraction.

questions.text: A 30 year old man complains of lower back pain. On examination, discoloration is noted on the ears. His urine sample turns black on standing. Which enzyme deficiency is expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
ALKAPTONURIA

  • d/t deficienty of Homogentisate dioxygenase (requires iron)
  • Rx
    • NITISINONE
  • Homogenetic acid accumulated → oxidised → Black coloured compound in urine
    • Fresh urine is normal in colour
    • On standing or exposed to air urine turns Black
  • Part of Garrod’s Tetrad:
    • Cystinuria
    • Alkaptonuria
    • Albinism
    • Pentosuria
  • Age of onset →30-40 yrs
  • presents with lower back pain
  • no MR
  • Homogentisic acid gets polymerized in to alkapton bodies which accumulates in:
  • Cartilages (Nose, Ear Pinna, IV discs) → Arthritis
  • Connective tissue → Bluish black colour Collectively, accumulation of homogentisic acid in all body parts is termed as Ochronosis and arthritis as Ochronotic arthritis.
  • Benedict’s test is positive d/t Homogentisic Acid (Reducing substance)
  • Diagnosis is by FeCl3 urine test → positive

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true?

Lipoprotein lipase is activated by insulin and breaks triglycerides in chylomicrons and VLDL.
VLDL transports exogenous triglycerides ( taken from diet) to the liver and adipose tissue.
The endogenous cholesterol is transported from liver to peripheral tissues in the form of LDL
HDL carries cholesterol ester and is associated with ACAT enzyme ( Acyl-CoA cholesterol acyl transferase)
questions.solution:
Lipoprotein Lipase (LPL)
  • Present in endothelium cells
  • Anabolic enzyme
  • Activated by insulin only in capillary bed of adipose tissue
  • Breaks TG present in chylomicrons and VLDL when they pass through adipose tissues.

Chylomicron Transport Exogeneous Fat or Exogeneous TG From intestine to peripheral Tissue.

Chylomicron remnant Formed is transported back to liver.

Funcion of LDL:

  • Cholesterol is required for membrane, vitamin D and steriod hormone synthesis in peripheral cells
  • LDL provide cholesterol to peripheral Tissues

questions.text: A 36-year-old man arrives at his doctor's office with a fever and a headache. On examination, he showed signs of leukopenia and elevated liver enzymes, as well as inclusion bodies in his monocytes. questions.solution:
Ehrlichiosis is most likely causing the symptoms.

  • All the listed diseases except Q fever are tick-borne.

Points in favour of Ehrlichiosis :

Two human forms of ehrlichiosis can occur:

  • Human monocyticehrlichiosis (HME), caused by E. chaffeensis
  • Human granulocytic ehrlichiosis (HGE), caused by Ehrlichia phagocytophila

HME infection is transmitted by the brown dog tick and A. americanum.
HGE infection is transmitted by I. scapularis,the same tick that transmits Lyme disease.

  • Both infections causefever and leukopenia.

Answer to other options:

questions.text: What is an example of a seasonal trend of a disease?

choices.text: Upper respiratory infection in winter season
Road accidents occurring more on weekends

questions.solution:
Periodic Fluctuations

This means occurrence of a disease in a community during a definite priod, either in a particular season or periodically in a cyclic form. Accordingly, there are two types: Seasonal trend and cyclic trend.

Seasonal Trend

Some diseases occur in a definite season.

  • Measles and chickenpox in the early spring season
  • Upper respiratory infection in the winter season
  • Diarrheal diseases during summer months.

The seasonal trend of the disease is because of the favorable environmental factors such as humidity, rainfall, atmospheric temperature, overcrowding, etc.

Cyclic Trend

This means tendency of a diease to occur cyclically once in several days, weeks, months or years. Examples: Epidemic of measles once in 2 to 3 years, rubella once in 6 to 9 years, influenza once in 7 to 10 years. Accidents more on weekends.

Thus, the knowledge on periodic fluctuations helps to protect the community.

Long-term Fluctuations (secular Trend)

This means changes in the occurrence of the disease over a long period of time, several years or decades. For example, coronary heart disease, diabetes, lung cancer have shown an upward trend in the developed countries during the last 50 years, followed by a downward trend of diseases like leprosy, tuberculosis, typhoid, amoebiasis, etc.

Thus, studying the time distribution of a diseae helps the epidemiologist not only to formulate an etiological hypothesis but also to implement prevention and control measures.

questions.text: Which of the following option does not describe the pathophysiology in Diabetic Nephropathy?

choices.text: Thickening of the GBM and diffuse increase in mesangial matrix with mild proliferation of mesangial cells with fibrin cap.
Nodules that are PAS-positive and contain lipid and fibrin which enlarge and compress the glomerular capillaries and obliterate the glomerular tuft.
An eosinophilic hyaline thickening of the parietal layer of Bowman’s capsule called capsular drop that bulges into the glomerular space.
GBM considerably thickened, which with silver stains shows two basement membranes with a clear zone between them.

questions.solution:
MORPHOLOGIC FEATURES. Diabetic nephropathy encompasses 4 types of renal lesions in diabetes mellitus: diabetic glomerulosclerosis, vascular lesions, diabetic pyelonephritis and tubular lesions (Armanni-Ebstein lesions).

  1. DIABETIC GLOMERULOSCLEROSIS. Glomerular lesions in diabetes mellitus are particularly common and account for majority of abnormal findings referable to the kidney.

Pathogenesis of these lesions in diabetes mellitus is explained by following sequential changes: hyper-glycaemia →glomerular hypertension → renal hyper-perfusion → deposition of proteins in the mesangium →glomerulosclerosis →renal failure. In addition, cellular infiltration in renal lesions in diabetic glomerular lesions is due to growth factors, particularly transforming growth factor-β. Strict control of blood glucose level and control of systemic hypertension in these patients retards progression to diabetic nephropathy. Clomerulosclerosis in diabetes may take one of the 2 forms: diffuse or nodular lesions:

  1. Diffuse glomerulosclerosis. Diffuse glomerular lesions are the most common. There is involvement of all parts of glomeruli. The pathologic changes consist of thickening of the GBM and diffuse increase in mesangial matrix with mild proliferation of mesangial cells. Various exudative lesions such as capsular hyaline drops and fibrin caps may also be present. Capsular drop is an eosinophilic hyaline thickening of the parietal layer of Bowman's capsule and bulges into the glomerular space.Fibrin cap is homogeneous, brightly eosinophilic material appearing on the wall of a peripheral capillary of a lobule.
  2. Nodular glomerulosclerosis. Nodular lesions of diabetic glomerulosclerosis are also called as Kimmelstiel-Wilson (KW) lesions or intercapillary glomerulosclerosis. These lesions are specific for type 1 diabetes (juvenile-onset diabetes) or islet cell antibody-positive diabetes mellitus. The pathologic changes consist of one or more nodules in a few or many glomeruli. Nodule is an ovoid or spherical, laminated, hyaline, acellular mass located within a lobule of the glomerulus. The nodules are surrounded peripherally by glomerular capillary loops which may have normal or thickened GBM . The nodules are PAS-positive and contain lipid and fibrin. As the nodular lesions enlarge, they compress the glomer-ular capillaries and obliterate the glomerular tuft . As a result of glomerular and arteriolar involvement, renal ischaemia occurs leading to tubular atrophy and interstitial fibrosis and grossly small, contracted kidney.

questions.text: A 65 year old man presents with chronic dry cough and difficulty in breathing which is progressively increasing over the past 20 years. He gave a history of working in asbestos mining for the past 25 years. What histopathologic feature is expected in this patient?

choices.text: Dumb-bell shaped bodies coated with glycoprotein and hemosiderin which stain positively with Prussian Blue.
Hard, fibrotic nodules with concentric layers of collagen enclosed by fibroblasts and dust laden macrophages.
Non- casesating granulomas with acidophilic stellate shaped asteroid bodies
Coal macules composed of aggregates of dust-laden macrophages and collagen, present in alveoli and in bronchiolar walls.

questions.solution:
The 65 year old man who worked as a miner in asbestos industry presenting with a long history of chronic dry cough and dysnea has asbestosis of lungs.

In nature, asbestos exists as long thin fibrils which are fire-resistant and can be spun into yarns and fabrics suitable for thermal and electrical insulation and has many applications in industries. Particularly at risk are workers engaged in mining, fabrication and manufacture of a number of products from asbestos such as asbestos pipes, tiles, roofs, textiles, insulating boards, sewer and water conduits, brake lining, clutch castings etc.

Histologically, there is presence of characteristic asbestos which are asbestos fibers coated with glycoprotein and hemosiderin and appear beaded or dumbbell shaped. The coating stains positively for Prussian blue reaction.

Hard, fibrotic nodules with concentric layers of collagen enclosed by fibroblasts and dust laden macrophages are seen in silicosis. The silicotic nodules are located in the region of respiratory bronchioles, adjacent alveoli, pulmonary arteries, in the pleura and the regional lymph nodes. The silicotic nodules consist of central hyalinised material with scanty cellularity and some amount of dust. The hyalinised centre is surrounded by concentric laminations of collagen which is further enclosed by more cellular connective tissue, dust-filled macrophages and a few lymphocytes and plasma cells. Some of these nodules may have calcium deposits.

Non-caseatinggranulomas with acidophilicstellate shaped asteroid bodies are present in chronic berrylliosis. The disease is a cell- mediated hypersensitivity reaction in which the metal beryllium acts as a hapten. The condition is characterised by development of non-caseatingepithelioidgranulomas like those of sarcoidosis. These granulomas are diffusely scattered throughout the lung parenchyma. The granulomas have giant cells which frequently contain 3 types of inclusions:

  1. Birefringent crystals.
  2. Concentrically-laminated haematoxyphilic Schaumann or conchoid bodies.
  3. Acidophilicstellate-shaped asteroid bodies.

Coal macules composed of aggregates of dust-laden macrophages and collagen, present in alveoli and in bronchiolar walls are seen in coal-workers’ pneumoconiosis. The macrophages phagocytose large amount of coal dust particles which are then passed into the interstitial tissue of the lung and aggregate around respiratory bronchiole and cause focal dust emphysema.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is NOT true?

choices.text: Permanent tissues like cardiac muscle and nerves cannot undergo hyperplasia but can hypertrophy
Xerophthalmia due to vitamin A deficiency is an example of dysplasia
Under persistent stress, metaplasia can progress to dysplasia and eventually cancer

questions.solution:
Any change in stress to an organ- increase or decrease, may bring about a number of physiologic and morphologic cellular adaptations. The adaptive responses may be-

  • Hypertrophy
  • Hyperplasia
  • Atrophy
  • Metaplasia

Hyperplasia is an increase in the number of cells without increase in size in an organ or tissue (by contrast hypertrophy refers to an increase in the size of cells). Hyperplasia takes place if the cellular population is capable of synthesizing DNA, thus permitting mitotic division. Permanent tissues like cardiac muscles, skeletal muscles and nerves, however, cannot make new cells and undergo hypertrophy only. Generally, hyperplasia and hypertrophy occur together eg physiologically growth of pregnant uterus. An example of pathologic hyperplasia is endometrialhyperplasia in Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome where excess estrogen causes abnormal multiplication of cells.

Metaplasia is defined as a reversible change of one type of epithelial or mesenchymal adult cells to another type of adult epithelial or mesenchymal cells, usually in response to abnormal stimuli, and often reverts back to normal on removal of stimulus. However, if the stimulus persists for a long time, epithelial metaplasia may transform into cancer. Examples of metaplasia are-

A) Columnar metaplasia in Barrett’s esophagus, in which there is change of normal squamous epithelium to columnar epithelium

B) In vitamin A deficiency the conjunctival thin specialized squamous epithelium changes to keratinized stratified squamous epithelium. In vitamin A deficiency apart from xerophthalmia, there is squamous metaplasia in the nose, bronchi, urinary tract, lacrimal and salivary glands.

Dysplasia means ‘disordered cellular development’, often accompanied with metaplasia and hyperplasia; it is therefore also referred to as atypical hyperplasia. Dysplastic changes often occur due to chronic irritation or prolonged inflammation. On removal of the inciting stimulus, the changes may disappear. In a proportion of cases, however, dysplasia progresses into carcinoma in situ (cancer confined to layers superficial to basement membrane) or invasive cancer.

Uterine cervical dysplasia, high grade lesion. It shows increased number of layers of squamous epithelium having marked cytologic atypia including mitoses.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is NOT true about leukemia?

choices.text: Acute lymphoblastic leukemia is the most common type of leukemia in children
t (12;21) has better prognosis than t (9;22)
The blasts in ALL are positive for MPO
T-ALL is less common than B-ALL and presents more as mediastinal mass

questions.solution:
Myeloperoxidase (MPO) is an enzyme present in the primary granules of mature and immature cells of myeloid series. Leukemic myeloblasts are positive (AML M1, M2, M3 and M4 blasts and Auer rods). Lymphoblasts and normoblasts lack MPO. Thus, useful in differentiating AML from ALL.

Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia/Lymphoma (ALL) is a group of neoplasms consisting of lymphoblasts. Lymphoblast is immature, precursor B (pre­B) or T (pre­T) lymphocyte.

B lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma (about 85%) is more common than T lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma. It is seen in childhood and present as acute leukemias.

T lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma (15%) present in adolescent males as lymphomas, often with involvement of mediastinum (thymus).

questions.text: Which of the following can help in minimizing confounding?

choices.text: Ensuring proper matching between cases and controls
Selecting cases and controls in such a way that they differ

questions.solution:
It is a process of selection of controls in such a way that not only they resemble cases (study group) in all the attributes and free from the disease under study but also free from the ‘Confounding factor’. A confounding factor is the one which is not only associated with ‘exposure’ under investigation but also independently can act a ‘risk-factor’ for the development of the disease under study.

For example, in a study of role of alcohol in the etiology of esophageal cancer, smoking is a confounding factor. That means smoking, which is invariably associated with alcoholism can independently result in cancer of esophagus.

Confounding can be removed by MATCHING which ensures equal distribution of confounding factors in both the groups. It is the most common and simplest method use to remove confounding bias.

questions.text: A 15 year old boy presents with sore throat, fatigue and fever since a week. On examination, generalized lymphadenopathy and spleen enlargement is noted too. Monospot test detects heterophile antibodies. Which of the following cells would be detected in peripheral blood smear in this patient?
questions.solution:
The case in the vignette describes a classic case of Infectious Mononucleosis. Atypical T cells: Out of the total lymphocytes in the peripheral blood, essential to the diagnosis of IM is the presence of at least 10-12% atypical T cells (or mononucleosis cells). The mononucleosis cells are variable in appearance and are classed as Downey type I, II and III, of which Downey type I are found most frequently. These atypical T lymphocytes are usually of the size of large lymphocytes (12-16 μm diameter). The nucleus, rather than the usual round configuration, is oval, kidney-shaped or slightly lobate due to indentation of nuclear membrane and contains relatively fine chromatin without nucleoli, suggesting an immature pattern but short of leukaemic features. The cytoplasm is more abundant, basophilic and finely granular and may contain vacuoles. The greatest number of atypical lymphocytes is found between 7th to 10th day of the illness and these cells may persist in the blood for up to 2 months.

Reed Sternberg Cells are hallmark of Hodgkin Lymphoma.

Megaloblasts are abnormal, large, nucleated erythroid precursors, having nuclear-cytoplasmic asynchrony i.e., the nuclei are less mature than the development of cytoplasm. The megaloblastic form is due to impaired DNA synthesis from folate and/or vitamin B12 deficiencies and have hypersegmented nucleus.

Metamyelocytes- All forms of granulocytes are produced in the bone marrow and are termed, ‘myeloid series’. Myeloid series include maturing stages: myeloblast (most primitive precursor), promyelocyte, myelocyte, metamyelocyte, band forms and segmented granulocyte (mature form). Normally the bone marrow contains more myeloid cells than the erythroid cells in the ratio of 2:1 to 15:1 (average 3:1), the largest proportion being that of metamyelocytes, band forms and segmented neutrophils.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about emphysema is false?

choices.text: In smokers, panacinar emphysema is commonly seen
In PIMZ gene defect there is decreased alpha 1 antitrypsin and in PIZZ there is complete absence of enzyme
Secondary pneumothorax may occur due to rupture of bullae in emphysema.

questions.solution:
Emphysema is a chronic lung disease character­ ized by abnormal irreversible (permanent) dilatation of the airspaces distal to the terminal bronchiole. This is associated with destruction of their walls but without obvious fibrosis. Recent evidences show that small airway fibrosis is present which contributes to airflow obstruction.

Emphysema is classified according to its anatomic distribution (location of the lesions) within the lobule into four major types:

  1. centriacinar,
  2. panacinar,
  3. paraseptal
  4. irregular.

Centriacinar emphysema involves proximal parts of acini (spares alveoli) and is severe in upper lobes. Occurs in heavy smokers and in association with chronic bronchitis and coal-worker’s pneumoconiosis. Seen as most common type clinically.

In panacinar (panlobular) emphysema all the air spaces beyond terminal bronchiole are more or less uniformly/equally dilated. In contrast to centriacinar emphysema, more common in the lower lobes, and is usually most severe at the bases. It is associated with alpha 1antitrypsin deficiency.

Distal acinar (paraseptal) emphysema: Involves distal air spaces and are prone to spontaneous rupture → pneumothorax.

In irregular (scar or cicatricial) emphysema acinus is irregularly involved and is associated with scars/fibrosis.

questions.text: The syndrome in which colon cancer appears at a relatively younger age (<50 years) and is associated with multiple primary cancers at different sites (e.g. endometrium, ovary) has which mutations ?

choices.text: Mutations in tumor suppressor gene APC

questions.solution:
Hereditary non-polyposis colonic cancer (HNPCC or Lynch syndrome). HNPCC is an autosomal dominant condition in which colorectal cancer is seen in at least two generations of first-degree relatives before the age of 50 years, without evidence of familial polyposis coli. There are germline mutations in mismatch repair genes, human mutL homolog abbreviated as hMLH2 located on chromosome 2 and hMLH1 on chromosome 3 resulting in DNA instability. In HNPCC, colon cancer appears at a relatively younger age (<50 years), association with multiple primary cancers at different sites (e.g. endometrium, ovary), preferred location in proximal colon and better prognosis than other sporadic colon cancer cases.

Loss of APC gene and subsequent loss of K-RAS is part of adenoma-carcinoma sequence of colon cancer.

questions.text: In the emergency room, the attending quizzes you on your fundamental knowledge of local anaesthetics and their applications. She wants you to find the drug that can be applied topically (for example, to mucous membranes) but not given parenterally due to its physicochemical properties, which make it very poorly soluble. Which of the drugs listed below is the greatest solution to her question?
questions.solution: Nearly all local anesthetics contain a lipophilic functional group, and most have a hydrophilic group (e.g., amine). Benzocaine does not contain the terminal hydrophilic group; thus, it is only slightly soluble in water and is extraordinarily slowly absorbed. It is, therefore, only useful as a topical anesthetic (e.g., on mucous membranes).

questions.text: With a productive cough, a temperature, and rigours, a 67-year-old man visits the emergency room. Because he is allergic to penicillin, his chest radiograph shows right upper zone consolidation, and he is started on clarithromycin antibiotics. On admission, his CURB-65 score was 2. Ramipril 5 mg once a day, metformin 1 g twice a day, and simvastatin 40 mg at night are his current medications. What changes should be made to his medications?
questions.solution:
• Clarithromycin is a macrolide antibiotic and is a potent CYP3A4 inhibitor. Clarithromycin is contraindicated with the use of simvastatin. This is because clarithromycin can alter the metabolism of simvastatin leading to an increase in plasma levels and therefore increasing the risk of myopathy and rhabdomyolysis.
  • There is no indication to reduce his metformin dose. Unless he has developed an acute kidney injury or his blood pressure remains low (both parameters not given), there is no indication to reduce his ACE inhibitor.

The CURB-65 score has also been mentioned in this question. It is worth knowing that the score is a predictor of 30 day mortality for community acquired pneumonia and ranges from a score of 0 to 5. It is made up of

  • Confusion
  • Urea (> 7 mmol/L)
  • Respiratory rate (30 bpm or above)
  • BP (< 90/60)
  • Age (65 years or above)

questions.text: Which among the following is the last organ to putrify:

The various organsputrefyat different rates, depending on their structure, vascularity and access of air and bacteria. As a general rule, the organs show putrefactive changes in the following order:

  1. Larynx and trachea.
  2. Stomach, intestines, pancreas and spleen.
  3. Liver, lungs.
  4. Brain.
  5. Heart.
  6. Kidneys, bladder.

questions.text: Which of these is an example of coagulative necrosis?
questions.solution:
In coagulative necrosis the cause is Ischemia caused by obstruction in a vessel. Coagulative necrosis is characteristically seen in infarct of solid organs. In coagulative necrosis, the structural outlines of dead cells is preserved (tomb stone appearance). Organs affected: All organs except the brain. More frequent in heart, kidney, spleen and limb (dry gangrene). GrossAppearance: Involved region appear dry, pale, yellow and firm. It is wedge-shaped in organs like kidney and spleen. On Microscopy dead tissue retains its outline. Nucleus may be either absent or show karyolysis.

Liquefaction or colliquative necrosis occurs commonly due to ischemic injury and bacterial or fungal infections. It occurs due to degradation of tissue by the action of powerful hydrolytic enzymes. In Pancreatitis, the proteolytic enzymes from pancreas causes liquefactive necrosis. In brain infarction and abscess, the proteolytic enzymes from microglial cells and neutrophils respectively lyse the cells and protein, resulting in liquefactive necrosis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about amyloidosis is NOT true?

choices.text: Multiple myeloma shows AL (light chain proteins) type deposits
Senile cardiac amyloidosis associated protein is beta 2 microglobin
In Alzheimer’s disease, deposit of amyloid is seen as Congophilic angiopathy (amyloid material in the walls of cerebral blood vessels), neurofibrillary tangles and in senile plaques.

questions.solution:
Amyloidosis is the term used for a group of diseases characterised by extracellular deposition of fibrillar proteinaceous substance called amyloid having common morphological appearance, staining properties and physical structure but with variable protein (or biochemical) composition.

Primary amyloidosis consisting of AL fibril proteins is systemic or generalised in distribution. About 30% cases of AL amyloid have some form of plasma cell dyscrasias, most commonly multiple myeloma (in about 10% cases), and less often other monoclonal gammopathies such as Waldenstro?m’s macroglobulinaemia, heavy chain disease, solitary plasmacytoma and nodular malignant lymphoma (B cell lymphoma).

The second form of systemic or generalised amyloidosis is reactive or inflammatory or secondary in which the fibril proteins contain AA amyloid. Secondary or reactive amyloidosis occurs typically as a complication of chronic infectious (e.g. tuberculosis, bronchiectasis, chronic osteomyelitis, chronic pyelonephritis, leprosy, chronic skin infections), non-infectious chronic inflammatory conditions associated with tissue destruction (e.g. autoimmune disorders such as rheumatoid arthritis, inflammatory bowel disease), some tumours (e.g. renal cell carcinoma, Hodgkin’s disease) and in familial Mediterranean fever, an inherited disorder.

Senile cardiac amyloidosis (ATTR). Senile cardiac amyloidosis is seen in 50% of people above the age of 70 years. The deposits are seen in the heart and aorta. The type of amyloid in these cases is ATTR but without any change in the protein structure of TTR.

Senile cerebral amyloidosis (Aβ, APrP). Senile cerebral amyloidosis is heterogeneous group of amyloid deposition of varying etiologies that includes sporadic, familial, hereditary and infectious. Some of the important diseases associated with cerebral amyloidosis and the corresponding amyloid proteins are: Alzheimer's disease (Aβ), Down's syndrome (Aβ) and transmissible spongioform encephalopatheis (APrP) such as in Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, fatal familial insomnia, mad cow disease, kuru.

In Alzheimer's disease, deposit of amyloids is seen as Congophilic angiopathy (amyloid material in the walls of cerebral blood vessels), neurofibrillary tangles and in senile plaques.

questions.text: A new chemotherapy drug is invented that significantly increases the survival of patients suffering from lung carcinoma. If widely implemented, what change in disease occurrence would be most expected amongst the options listed?
questions.solution:
Incidence rate: It is the number new cases of a particular disease occurring per 1000 population in a year.

Prevalence rate: It is the total number of both old and new cases existing in the population during a given period or time. It is expressed in percentage, i.e. percentage of the population suffering from a particular disease.

Chronic diseases treatment that increase the survival of patients (eg in this case a new chemotherapy regimen that increases survival in lung cancer patients) increase the prevalence by increasing the pool of the people suffering from that disease without altering the incidence. Since incidence is new cases of a particular disease detected, thus it would not be affected by introduction of a drug that alters the survival of patients suffering from a chronic disease.

On the contrary, introducing a test that detects chronic disease more accurately increases both the incidence (new cases detected) and prevalence (total no. of cases, both old and new existing in a population).

questions.text: A 40 year old female patient is diagnosed with disseminated intravascular coagulation after delivering a 4 kg baby by caesarean section. What set of findings are expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation- Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), also termed defibrination syndrome or consumption coagulopathy, is a complex thrombo-haemorrhagic disorder (intravascular coagulation and haemorrhage) occurring as a secondary complication in some systemic diseases.

Clinical features:- There are 2 main features of DIC - bleeding as the most common manifestation, and organ damage due to ischaemia caused by the effect of widespread intravascular thrombosis such as in the kidney and brain. less common manifestations include: mciroangiopathic haemolytic anaemia and thrombosis in larger arteries and veins.

laboratory findings: the laboratory investigations include the following:

  1. The platelet count is low
  2. blood film shows the features of microangiopathic haemolytic anaemia. There is presence of schistocytes and fragmented red cells due to damage caused by trapping and passage through the fibrin thrombi.
  3. prothrombin time, thrombin time and atcivated partial thromboplastin time, are all prolonged
  4. plasma fibrinogen levels are reduced due to consumption in microvascular coagulation
  5. fibrin degradation products (FDPs) are raised due to secondary fibrinolysis.

questions.text: Relative risk is used in which type of study?
questions.solution:
Relative risk (Risk ratio): Risk ratio (RR) is the ratio of the incidence of the disease among exposed and the incidence of the disease among unexposed. It is a direct measure of the strength of the association between the suspected cause and the disease. It is used to measure the strength of association between risk factor and the outcome in a cohort study.

Example: 2,000 smokers and 1,000 matched nonsmokers were followed-up. Lung cancer developed in 120 smokers and 20 nonsmokders. Estimate the strength of the association between smoking and lung cancer by the appropriate indicators. Framework
Smoking Developed lung cancer Not developed lung cancer Total
Present 120 (a) 1880 (b) 2,000
Absent 20 (c) 980 (d)

1,000

RR 3 means, smokers are relatively 3 times at a greater risk of developing lung cancer than nonsmokers.

Note:

RR1 indicates no association.

RR greater than 1 indicates positive association and

RR lesser than 1 indicates negative association

questions.text:
A 55 year old man presents with painless swelling in the neck, fatigue, weight loss and night sweats since 8 months. On examination, painless, rubbery and discrete cervical lymphadenopathy is noted. Biospy is done of the mass and it reveals the following-

What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The vignette and histopathological picture points to Hodgkin’s disease. Hodgkin’s disease (HD) primarily arises within the lymph nodes and involves the extranodal sites secondarily. The Reed-Sternberg cells are the characterstic cells in Hodgkin Lymphoma. Classic RS cell is a large cell which has characteristically a bilobed nucleus appearing as mirror image of each other but occasionally the nucleus may be multilobed. Each lobe of the nucleus contains a prominent, eosinophilic, inclusion- like nucleolus with a clear halo around it, giving an owl-eye appearance. The cytoplasm of cell is abundant and amphophilic.

Hodgkin’s disease is particularly frequent among young and middle-aged adults. All histologic subtypes of HD, except the nodular sclerosis variety, are more common in males. The disease usually begins with superficial lymph node enlargement and subsequently spreads to other lymphoid and non-lymphoid structures.

  • Most commonly, patients present with painless, movable and firm lymphadenopathy. The cervical and mediastinal
  • The lymph nodes are involved most frequently. Other lymph node groups like axillary, inguinal and abdominal are involved sometimes. Approximately half the patients develop splenomegaly during the course of the disease. Liver enlargement too may occur.
  • Constitutional symptoms (type B symptoms) are present in 25-40% of patients. The most common is low-grade fever with night sweats and weight loss. Other symptoms include fatigue, malaise, weakness and pruritus.

WHO Classification (2016) of Hodgkin Lymphoma

  • Classical Hodgkin lymphoma (CHL)
    • nodular sclerosis classical hodgkin lymphoma (NSCHL)
    • mixed cellularity classical hodgkin lymphoma (MCCHL)
    • lymphocyte-rich classical Hodgkin lymphoma (LRCHL)
    • lymphocyte depleted classical hodgkin lymphoma (LDCHL)
  • Nodular lymphocyte predominant hodgkin lymphoma (NLPHL)

questions.text: Shortly after commencing antihypertensive medication, a 60-year-old man had ankle swelling. What is the MOST LIKELY antihypertensive drug to be the source of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
One of the known side effects of calcium channel blockers is swelling of the ankle. Calcium channel blockers widen the narrow blood vessels (vasodilation), causing redistribution of fluid from the vascular space, and for some people, this can cause more fluid to leak out of the blood into the tissues around the ankle resulting in swelling.

Calcium channel blockers can be divided into two types, the dihydropyridines, which are predominantly vasodilator and generally have neutral or increased effects on vascular permeability (Amlodipine and Nifedipine); and the non-dihydropyridines (verapamil and diltiazem) which reduce vascular permeability and affect cardiac contractility and conduction. All of these can cause ankle swelling.

Calcium channel blockers:

  • Most common side effect is headache
  • CCB cause flushing, headache, angioedema, reflex tachycardia.
  • Verapamil, diltiazem- both vasodilation and decrease in heart rate
  • Nifedipine, clevidipine - only vasodilation but increase in heart rate. Avoid in angina

questions.text: Milnacipran prevents the reuptake of
Amiloride is an effective treatment for hypokalemia caused by other medications. Which of the following statements best illustrates how amiloride exerts its potassium-sparing effects?

choices.text: Blocks the agonist effects of aldosterone with its renal tubular receptors
Blocks distal tubular sodium channels and, ultimately, Na+ -K+ exchange
Suppresses cortisol and aldosterone synthesis and release in the adrenal cortex

questions.solution:
Amiloride and triamterene block distal tubular Na+ channels that provide for Na+ reabsorption in exchange for K+ , which is lost into the urine. This sodium channel, which is the main site of action of amiloride, is on the luminal side of the principal cell membranes. (Principal cells in the nephron are located in the late distal tubule and collecting ducts.) There is an ATPase on the interstitial face of the principal cells (again, these are in the distal nephron, not proximal; d). The ATPase is responsible for the extrusion of potassium into the urine in exchange for extra sodium taken up by the luminal sodium channels, and so it is essential in the overall actions of potassium-sparing diuretics. Nonetheless, the ATPase is not inhibited (or stimulated; d) directly by amiloride.

Amiloride has no direct effects on aldosterone synthesis or metabolism (c), or on aldosterone receptors (a; those receptors are blocked by spironolactone)

questions.text: A 60 year old male is diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia, t(15;17). What is the pathway or receptor on which the treatment of this patient’s AML acts on?
questions.solution:
AML is a neoplasm of hematopoietic progenitors char­acterized by proliferation resulting in accumulation of immature myeloblasts in the marrow. Acute promyelocytic leukemia is characterized by t (15;17) which involves translocation of retinoic acid receptor (RAR) from chromosome 17 to chromosome 15. The RAR disruption causes block in maturation and promyelocytes (blasts) accumulate. Treatment with ATRA (all trans-retinoic acid) which is a Vitamin A derivative, binds to the altered receptor and causes the blasts to mature.

Imatinib, a tyrosine kinase inhibitor, is used in CML.

Cladribine is a drug with adenosine deaminase inhibitor, used in hairy cell leukemia.

questions.solution: Alport Disease is an X-linked dominant disorder having mutation in α−5 chain of type IV collagen located on X-chromosome. It affects males more severely than females. The syndrome consists of sensorineural deafness and ophthalmic complications (lens dislocation, posterior cataracts and corneal dystrophy) associated with hereditary nephritis. The condition is slowly progressive, terminating in end-stage kidney in the 2nd to 3rd decades of life. The common presenting features are persistent or recurrent haematuria accompanied by erythrocyte casts, proteinuria and hypertension. It is NOT due to cell mediated damage to glomeruli.

questions.text: A patient experiences periodic episodes of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia . Which of the following medications would be best for outpatient prevention of these dangerous electrophysiologic events?
questions.solution:
Verapamil, a nondihydropyridine calcium channel blocker (CCB), depresses both the SA node and the AV node and would be effective for prophylaxis of paroxysmal atrial or supraventricular tachycardia.

Nifedipine (c), the prototypic dihydropyridine CCB, has little effect on SVT because it and the other dihydropyridines lack cardiac depressant effects. Moreover, if we chose a fast-/ immediate-acting dosage form of nifedipine, we would probably trigger substantial reflex cardiac stimulation. The increased sympathetic tone to the heart could worsen the PSVT.

Nitroglycerin (d) is mainly a venodilator, but it can cause falls of arterial blood pressure sufficient to trigger reflex cardiac activation that would exacerbate the tachydardia. Adenosine (a) may be useful in diagnosing whether ventricular tachycardia is of supraventricular or ventricular origin, because it effectively slows AV nodal conduction. It is also used as acute therapy for PSVT. However, it is a fast-and-shortacting parenteral drug, which renders it unsuitable for the condition we stated: outpatient prophylaxis. Lidocaine (b) is mainly used for ventricular tachyarrhythmias, not those of supraventricular origin. Both adenosine and lidocaine are parenteral drugs with short half-lives; neither property makes them suitable for outpatient prophylactic use.

questions.text: A 69-year-old man presents with a history of prostate cancer stage 4. He's had back discomfort for the past year, which he's been able to manage with oral morphine. As his back pain worsened, his morphine dose was raised during the last few weeks. He's been vomiting and feeling terrible since then. The palliative team stopped the oral morphine and replaced it with a fentanyl patch, and he was started on metoclopramide. He suffers neck stiffness, high fevers, pallor, profuse sweating, and muscle tightness a few weeks after changing drugs. What is the MOST LIKELY CAUSE of these signs and symptoms?
questions.solution:
• Extrapyramidal side effects are a very common side effect of metoclopramide which is an antidopaminergic drug. Symptoms include dystonia, akathisia, parkinsonims, bradykinesia, tremors.
  • The high fever in this stem could represent a syndrome called neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS). Neuroleptic malignant syndrome is a life threatening reaction that occurs in response to neuroleptic or antipsychotic medications (usually haloperidol). Metoclopramide is one of the medications that may induce neuroleptic malignant syndrome. Symptoms usually include high fevers, confusion, agitation, muscle rigidity, sweating and tachycardia. The onset of these symptoms usually occurs after a few weeks of starting the medication but the symptoms can occur at any time.
  • NEUROLEPTIC MALIGNANT SYNDROME Neuroleptic malignant syndrome is a rare but life-threatening reaction to antidopaminergic medications. Onset is usually wthin a few weeks fo starting the antidopaminergic medication but can occur at any time.
  • Features
    • High fever
    • Rigidity
    • Confusion or altered consciousness
    • Variable blood pressure
    • Tachycardia
  • Management
    • Stop offending medication
    • Rapid cooling
    • Dantrolene- drug of choice

  • TZANCK Smear: TZANCK CELLS (Multinucleated giant cells).

questions.solution:
LIKELIHOOD RATIO OF A NEGATIVE RESULT (LR):

questions.text: A stomach biopsy was conducted on a patient with a peptic ulcer who was admitted to the hospital. The tissue was cultivated for 5 to 7 days on chocolate agar in a microaerophilic atmosphere at 37°C. Colonies developed on the plate after 5 days of incubation and were curved, Gram negative rods with oxidase activity. What is the organism's most likely identity?
questions.solution:
Helicobacter pyloriis the most likely organism.

The condition is suggestive ofPeptic ulcer diseasewhereepigastric painis the primary symptom.

  • This organism is readily isolated from gastric biopsies, but not from stomach contents.

Differentiating points from Camplyobacter jejuni:

  • H.pylorigrows more slowly than C. jejuni, requiring 5 to 7 days incubation.
  • C. jejuni grows optimally at 42°C,not 37°C, as does H. pylori.

HELICOBACTER PYLORI:

  • Gram negative bacilli
  • Micro aerophile
  • Motile
  • Strongly urease positive[Yellow → Pink]

Diseases caused by H. pylori:

  • PUD [PEPTIC ULCER DISEASE]
  • Maltoma
  • CA stomach

Pathophysiology: Following attachment to the gastric mucosa, H. pylori causes directmucosal damageby the combination ofammonia production (from the action of the organism’s urease on urea) and the host inflammatory response.

LAB DIAGNOSIS:

  • NON INVASIVE TESTS:→ Urea Breath Test with radio labelled C13orC14
  • INVASIVE TEST → Endoscopic Biopsy - Stain with WARTHIN STARRY SILVER STAIN

questions.text: Due to a typhoid outbreak in a village of 4000 population, 50 cases occurred and 5 died. Case fatality rate calculated is-
questions.solution: CFR represents the killing power of a disease. It is typically used in acute infectious diseases like measles, rabies, food poisoning, etc. because it is closely related to virulence of the organisms. Rabies has 100 percent CFR.

questions.text: Following medication delivery, we want to calculate some metric that most accurately reflects the total amount of drug reaching the target tissue(s) over time. We're administering the medication orally. Which of the following would be the most effective measure?

choices.text: Area under the blood concentration-time curve (AUC)
Product of the Vd and the first-order rate constant

questions.solution:
• Area under the curve (AUC)??' tells theExtent of absorption.

When compared with AUC of intravenous route, we get bioavailability.

  • Oral Bioavailability = AUC (oral)/AUC (IV)

We obtain the AUC orally and compare that value with the AUC obtained with giving the same drug intravenously (where bioavailability is, by definition, 1.0). The fraction of a drug dose absorbed after oral administration is affected by a variety of factors that can strongly influence the peak blood levels and the time-to-peak blood concentration. The Vd and the total body clearance also are important in determining the amount of drug that reaches the target tissue. Only the area under the blood concentration-time curve, however, reflects absorption, distribution, metabolism, and excretion factors; it is the most reliable method of evaluating bioavailability overall

questions.text: A sudden and irresistible desire foralcoholic drinksat periodic intervals is known as:
questions.solution:
All are examples of impulsiveness.

Impulse:This is a sudden and irresistible force compelling a person to the conscious performance of some action without motive or fore-thought.

As cognitive aspect is not impaired the person knows the nature of the act committed but unable to control himself. Considered as not guilty as per Irresistible impulse test, however, treated as guilty under IPC 84 (India)

Types of Impulse:

Kleptomania -an irresistible desire to steal articles of little value.

Pyromania- an irresistible desire to set things to fire.

Mutilomania- an irresistible desire to mutilate.

Dipsomania- an irresistible desire for alcoholic drinks at periodic intervals.

Sexual impulses- including sexual perversions.

Suicidal and homicidal impulses.

questions.text:
Match the following-



Iron Deficiency Anemia
Bite cells


Sideroblastic Anemia
Plummer-Vinson Syndrome


Hereditary Spherocytosis
Osmotic Fragility Test


Glucose-6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase Deficiency
B 6 Deficiency


Vitamin B12 deficiency
Increased Methylmalonic Acid
questions.solution:
Iron deficiency anemia is microcytic, hypochromic type of anemia. Long-standing chronic iron deficiency anemia causes epithelial tissue changes in some patients. Plummer-Vinson Syndrome is a manifestation of iron deficiency anemia characterized by upper esophageal webs and atrophic glossitis, which causes dysphagia and beefy-red tongue.

Sideroblastic anemia- Sideroblasticanemiasare a heterogeneous group of disorders that are unified pathologically by abnormal accumulation of mitochondrial iron and impairedheme synthesis. Isoniazid, an anti-tuberculous drug and a pyridoxine antagonist, is most commonly associated with development of sideroblastic anemia by producing abnormalities in pyridoxine metabolism. Vitamin B6 is a required cofactor of ALA Synthase enzyme which in turn is the rate limiting step of protoporhyrin synthesis. Deficiency of B6 causes decreased protoporphyrin production (essential in hemoglobin production), which causes sideroblastic anemia and entrapment of iron in mitochondria.

Hereditary Spherocytosis- The molecular abnormality in hereditary spherocytosis is a defect in proteins which anchor the lipid bilayer to the underlying cytoskeleton like spectrin and ankyrin. Osmotic fragility test is helpful in testing the spheroidal nature of red cells which lyse more readily in solutions of low salt concentration i.e. osmotic fragility is increased.

G6PD Deficiency- G6PD gene is located on the X chromosome and its deficiency is, therefore, a sex (X)-linked trait affecting males, while the females are carriers and are asymptomatic. However, these individuals develop hemolytic episodes on exposure to oxidant stress such as viral and bacterial infections, certain drugs (antimalarials, sulfonamides, nitrofurantoin, aspirin, vitamin K), metabolic acidosis and on ingestion of fava beans (favism). Individuals with inherited deficiency of G6PD, an enzyme required for hexose monophosphate shunt for glucose metabolism, fail to develop adequate levels of reduced glutathione in their red cells. This results in oxidation and precipitation of hemoglobin within the red cells forming Heinz bodies. Formation of Heinz bodies is visualized by means of supravital stains such as crystal violet, also called Heinz body hemolytic anemia. However, Heinz bodies are removed by the spleen, leading to formation of ‘bite cells’.

Megaloblastic anemia due to or folate can be distinguished by serum determination of methylmalonic acid and homocysteine by sophisticated enzymatic assays. Both are elevated in Vitamin B12 deficiency, while in folate deficiency there is only elevation of homocysteine and not of methylmalonic acid.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl appears to clinic with a steady decrease in her academic performance withhigh liver enzymes of unclear origin for several years. Hepatosplenomegaly, intention tremor, dysarthria, dysphagia and dystoniaare all present on examination.Her urinalysis revealed high glucose, protein, and uric acid levels. What is the ONE MOST LIKELY DISEASE?

choices.text: Autoimmune hepatitis is a type of autoimmune hepatitis

questions.solution:
• Wilson’s Disease
  • Presentation: - Kayser-Fleischer rings
    • Liver dysfunction → deranged liver function tests, cirrhosis
    • Neurological → ataxia, dysarthria, dystonia
    • Behavioural → personality changes, decreased school performance
  • Diagnosis:
    • Wilson’s disease scoring system → score > 4
    • Serum ceruloplasmin – initial
    • Measurement of hepatic parenchymal copper concentration - definitive
  • Treatment:
    • Choice of: D-penicillamine ; trientine ; ammonium tetrathiomolybdate
    • Neurological involvement - zinc - first line
    • Acute liver failure / cirrhosis - liver transplant – definitive

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents with dry mouth from the past 6 months. She complains that because of the dry mouth she has to drink a lot of water and juices. She also complains of sandy sensation in her eyes. Physical examination findings are within normal limits. Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Reassurance and re examination in 3 months

questions.solution:
This patient has dry mouth (xerostomia) and dry eyes (keratoconjunctivitis sicca). These sicca symptoms are extremely common, especially in the elderly (prevalence ~30%), where they may be due to medication usage or to age-related atrophy of tissues that secrete saliva and tears; they are also commonly associated with Sjogren syndrome, an infiltrative autoimmune condition that can affect multiple organ systems (eg, musculoskeletal pain, cutaneous manifestations, interstitial lung disease, hematologic abnormalities).

In patients with siccasymptoms, the choice of appropriate diagnostic modalities depends on the patient's age, past medical history, associated findings, and overall pretest probability of Sjogren syndrome. Theinitial evaluation can include ophthalmologic evaluation, including Schirmer test (slit-lamp examination to assess tear break-up time), as well as autoantibody screening with anti-Ro/SSA, anti-La/SSB, antinuclear antibodies, and rheumatoid factor.

questions.text: Which of the following high Risk cardiac lesion does NOT need Endocarditis prophylaxis before dental procedures?
questions.solution:
Antibiotic prophylaxis is not recommended against infective endocarditis for patients with mitral valve prolapse who are undergoing a dental procedure.

High risk cardiac lesion for which endocarditis prophylaxis is required, before dental procedures:

  1. Prosthetic valve
  2. Prior endocarditis
  3. Unrepaired CCHD
  4. Completely repaired CCHD, less then 6 months
  5. incomplete repair of CCHD
  6. Valuopathy after cardiac Tx

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient was admitted for emergency laparatomy under general anaesthesia due to sepsis caused by a hollow viscous perforation and peritonitis. His blood reports revealed HbA1c of 7.8./. In this scenario, the intravenous anaesthetic drug to avoid is-
questions.solution:
Etomidate inhibits 11-beta hydroxylase enzyme in adrenal cortex.

ETOMIDATE

Etomidate is a carboxylatedimidazole – containing anesthetic compound structurally unrelated to any other IV anesthetics.

Aqueous solution of etomidate is unstable at physiologic pH and a formulated in a 0.2% solution with 35% prophylene glycol.

Etomidate is rapidly metabolised by hydrolysis through hepatic microsomal enzymes and plasma esterases.Hydrolysis is nearly complete as only 3% of unchanged drug excreted in urine.The clearance is about 5 times that of thiopentone with short elimination half life of 2-3 hours and hepatic and renal function tests are not altered by etomidate.

Side Effects

  1. Adrenal cortex suppression
  • Inhibits the activity of 11-β- hydroxylase(dose dependent reversible inhibition),an enzyme necessary for the synthesis of cortisol, aldosterone ,17- hydroxyl-progesterone and corticosterone.
  • Inhibits the enzyme 11β-hydroxylase, → decreased biosynthesis of cortisol and mineralocorticoid and increases the formation intermediaries (11-deoxycorticosterone).
  • More potent inhibitor of steroid synthesis than as a sedative-hypnotic as the concentration which produces adrenocortical suppression(10 ng/mL) is much lower than that needed for hypnosis (>200 ng/mL).
  • Associated withadrenocortical suppressionwhich canlast upto 72 hours.

2. Pain on injection(can be reduced by injecting lignocaine immediately before etomidate injection),thrombophlebitis-less frequent incidence

3. High incidence of postoperative nausea and vomiting

4. Myoclonic activity(0-70%)-reduced by premedication with midazolam or small dose of magnesium 60-90 seconds before induction dose

5. Inhibit platelet function

6.Hiccups(0-70%)

7.Emergence delirium

Etomidate reduces cerebral blood blow by 34% and cerebral metabolic rate of oxygen by 45% without altering mean arterial pressure. Cerebral perfusion pressure is maintained or increased and a beneficial net increase in cerebral oxygen supply to demand ratio occurs. Etomidate also reduces intracranial pressure to 50% in patients with already increased intracranial pressure.

CBF ICP CMRO2
Thiopentone ↓↓↓ ↓↓↓ ↓↓↓
Ketamine ↑↑ ↑↑ ↑
etomidate ↓↓↓ ↓↓↓ ↓
propofol ↓↓↓ ↓↓↓ ↓↓↓
  • Cardiovascular stability is the characteristic feature of etomidate as it causes minimal changes in heart rate, stroke volume, cardiac output and mean arterial pressure may be decreased upto 15%.It can be used as an induction agent in patients with little or no cardiac reserve because no anaesthetic induced negative inotropic effects due to its lack of effect on preload, afterload, sympathetic nervous system and on the function of the baroreceptor.It differs from other intravenous anaesthetics in that depressive effects on myocardial contractility are minimal at concentrations needed to produce anaesthesia.The myocardial oxygen supply-to-demand ratio is well maintained. Hence, etomidate is the intravenous agent of choice in patients with coronary artery disease, cardiomyopathy and cerebral vascular disease.
  • Etomidate may stimulate ventilation independently of medullary centres that normally respond to carbon dioxide so it may be useful when maintenance of spontaneous ventilation is desirable.
  • With exception to etomidate, all IV induction agents cause allergic reactions and anaphylaxis.Etomidate has very low incidence of allergic reactions and does not release histamine from mast cells.

Uses

  • Cardiovascular disease-compromised cardiovascular system who are undergoing coronary artery bypass surgery
  • Reactive airway disease
  • Intracranial hypertension
  • Aortic aneurysm repair
  • Thoracic surgery
  • Neurosurgery-giantaneurysmal clipping
  • Trauma with questionable intravascular volume status
  • Cardioversion
  • Treatment of endogenous hypercortisolemia

questions.text: A 10 month old boy presents to the emergency with infantile spasms. On examination ash leaf macules are noted and a family history of subependymal giant cell astrocytoma and adenoma sebaceum is present in maternal uncle. What is the most probable neurocutaneous disorder expected in the 10 month old boy?
questions.solution:
PHAKOMATOSIS /neurocutaneous disorder

Tuberous sclerosis: AD

  • family history is present and TSC1 (chromosome 9) & TSC2 gene (chromosome 16) involvement
  • adenoma sebaceum - Acne like lesion in butterfly distribution

  • Shagreen patch- Irregular appearance of skin
  • Subungual Fibroma- fleshy growth From below the Nail

Earliest cutaneous manicestation

  • Ash- leaf macules = Hypopigmented macules on Trunk

CNS manifestations:-

  • < 1yr:Incantile spasm = Vigabatrin
  • >1yr : Focal/ seizures = Carbamazepine

On CT = Subependymal giant cell astrocytoma: slow growing - periventricular glioneuronal tumor

Lesion in Kidney = Angiomyolipoma (having Cat, muscle and blood vessel together)

Bleeding in angiomyolipoma of Tuberous sclerosis = Wunderlich syndrome

Sturge weber syndrome

  • Port wine statin
  • cavernous angioma
  • seizures (focal)
    • S - Seizure
    • T - Trigeminal nerve distribution
    • U - U/L weakness
    • R - Mental retardation
    • G - Glaucoma
    • E - eye = Buphthalmos

CT scan head: TRAM TRACK APPEARANCE

note:

TRAM TRACK APPEARANCE

  • CT scan head: Sturge weber syndrome
  • Chest X- ray: Bronchiectasis
  • kidney biopsy: MPGN

Von Hippel – Lindadu Disease AD. Deletion of VHL gene on chromosome 3p. pVHL ubiquintinates hypoxia inducible factor la. Heminagioblastomas (high vascularity with hyperchromatic nuclei i) in retina, brain stem, cerebellum, spine j; Abgiomatosis; bilateral Renal cell carcinomas; Pheochromocytomas
Neurofibromatosis type I AD, 100% penetrance. Mutation in NF1 tumor suppressor gene on chromosome 17 (encodes neurofibromin, a negative RAS regulator) Seizures / focal, Pheochromocytomas, Seizures / focal neurologic Signs (often from meningioma), bone lesions (eg, sphenoid dysplasia)

questions.text: A 6 year old boy presents to clinic with obesity. As an infant, he had a history of failure to thrive. He is now behind in school, has trouble communicating with his peers, and feeds on a regular basis. His mother claims he is unable to stop eating. What is the ONE MOST LIKELY DISEASE?

choices.text: Primary hypoparathyroidism (hypoparathyroidism) is a condition in which the thyroid gland

questions.solution:
• Prader Willi syndrome is a result of chromosomal abnormality in chromosome 15 on the paternal side. The key clue is behavioral problems and uncontrolled feeding habits. There may sometimes be clues in the stem stating the child has “blue eyes and blonde hair”.
  • Presentation:
    • Male with blonde hair, blue eyes
    • Behavioral problems
    • If uncontrolled feeding + obesity, the boy usually < 6 years old
    • Developmental delay
  • Diagnosis:
    • Chromosomal analysis: abnormality of paternal chromosome 15
    • Mostly clinical diagnosis

questions.text: A 22 year old woman who was diagnosed with a missed miscarriage a week ago now presents to the hospital because of abdominal pain. She says she passed a small fetus and a number of clots this morning. On examination, abdomen is tender, and cervical os is opened. A transvaginal ultrasound scan shows products of conception still present in the uterus. What is the single most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Products of conception still present in the uterus defines incomplete miscarriage.Some products of conception have been expelled but some still remain thus giving the diagnosis of incomplete miscarriage. There is usually pain and vaginal bleeding and the cervical os is open.

Types of abortions

Presentation P/V examination USG
Threatened abortion pain, bleeding os closed normal intrauterine pregnancy
Inevitable abortion pain, bleeding os open intrauterine pregnancy with dilated cervix
