Acidosis ,hypoxia, hypercapnia occur after seizure activity caused by rapid accidental intravascular injection of bupivacaine which exacerbates its intrinsic cardiac toxicity.

Premature ventricular contractions ,widening of the QRS complex and ventricular tachycardia are the most common arrhythmias seen with bupivacaine though supraventricular tachycardia ,atrioventricular heart block, ST, T wave changes can also occur but are less common. Cardiotoxic plasma concentration of bupivacaine is 8-10 μg/ml.

Plasma concentration of the local anaesthetic is determined by the rate of tissue distribution and the rate of clearance of the drug.

The rate and extent of systemic absorption depends on the site of injection, the dose and the intrinsic pharmacokinetic properties of the drug. After administration ,drug's plasma concentration is paralleled by an initial high uptake into the lungs and the distribution of the local anesthetic to highly perfused tissues ( brain, heart, kidneys). Lipid solubility is important in this redistribution and a primary determinant of intrinsic local anesthetic potency. After distributing into the highly perfused tissues, it is redistributed into less well perfused tissues(Skeletal muscles and fat).Consideration of cardiac output is important for describing the overall tissue distribution.

Patient related factors - Age, Cardiovascular status and hepatic function influences the absorption and resultant plasma concentration

Protein binding also influence the distribution and excretion .Less protein bound drugs will give increased proportion of active form of local anesthetic. Protein binding parallels lipid solubility of local anesthetic and is inversely related to the plasma concentration of the drug.

The risk factors for developing last (local anesthetic systemic toxicity)

Drug

The cardiovascular collapse (CC/ CNS) ratio is "the ratio of drug dose required to cause catastrophic cardiovascular collapse to the drug dose required ton produce seizures/ "A low CC/CNS ratio is associated with more cardiotoxic agents, while LAs with a higher CC/CNS ratio have a greater safety margin. This is because the earlier presentation of of CNS features may expedite earlier diagnosis (and thus, treatment) of LAST before cardiovascular collapse ensues. Ropivacaine and levobupivacaine, for example, have higher CC/CNS ratios than racemic bupivacaine. therefore, it seems logical to preferentially use these drugs when long-acting LAs are desired. vigilance always required, however, as all LA drugs may cause LAST.

Patient factors

  • Age
    • Patients at the extremes of age have been shown to be the greatest risk of LAST. Newborn infants have immature hepatic enzyme systems and elimination is prolonged. The potehntial for toxicity with lidocaine infusions is also increased by accumulation of its principle metabolite monethylglycinexylidide(MEGX) which can cause seizures
  • pregnancy
    • The effects of pregnancy on local anesthetic potency may reflect a combined effect of mechanical factors in pregnancy and (dilated epidural veins decrease the volume of the epidural and subarachnoid spaces) direct effects of hormones especially progesterone on the susceptibility of the nerves to conduction blcokade
    • hormone changes is more important of these two as the susceptibility is noted in the first trimester itself before gross changes in vascular dimensions of epidural or subarachnoid spaces occur. so the dose should be reduced in all stages of pregnancy
  • Renal Disease
    • Patients with severe renal disease not only have a hyperdynamic circulation and reduced clearance of LAs, but also have an increased alpha1 - acid glycoprotein concentration. As a result, free plasma concentration are largelt unchanged and dose reduction is often unnecessary. Unless the patient is uremic with metabolic acidosis.
  • cardiac disease
    • Dose reduction is unnecessary in mild-moderate heart failure where tissue is preserved, but is recommended in severe heart failure. The rate of disappearance of lignoaine from blood markedly prolonged in patients with congestive cardiac failure
  • Hepatic dysfunction
    • decreased hepatic blood flow are impaired hepatic enzyme function can produce elevation of blood levels of aminoamide local anesthetics. So dose reduction is necessary

on examination: CORD like structure palpated at TM joint

Rx OC:

Steroids

  • Aspirin 81 mg daily has been found to reduce occurrence of cranial ischemic complications in GCA.
  • Toclizumab is FDA approved for this indication

S/E:

questions.text: A 13-month-old female baby goes to the emergency room with breathing difficulties. She has intercostal recessions and a bilateral broad wheeze on examination. Her body temperature is 39.1 degrees Celsius, and her respiratory rate is 35breaths/minute. What is the ONE MOST LIKELY DISEASE?
questions.solution:
• Bronchiolitis is very common in infants and young children. Their early symptoms are of those of a viral upper respiratory tract infection including mild rhinorrhoea, cough and fever. The fever is usually high (above 39°C). Other symptoms of bronchiolitis include wheeze. Occasionally, one may find symptoms of cyanosis and poor feeding in the stem.
  • Bronchiolitis
    • An acute infectious disease of the lower respiratory tract that occurs primarily in the very young, most commonly infants between 2 and 6 months old
    • Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) is the pathogen in 75-80% of cases
  • It is a clinical diagnosis based upon:
    • Breathing difficulties
    • Cough
    • Coryzal symptoms (including mild fever)
    • Decreased feeding
    • Apnoeas in the very young
    • Wheeze or fine inspiratory crackles on auscultation
  • Management
    • Largely supportive involving humidified oxygen

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman goes to her general practitioner for her annual physical. She's had a lump in her breast for two years and has yet to seek medical help. For the past two years, the bulk has kept the same size. The mass is felt as a hard 3 cm by 2 cm mass on examination and is placed on the right upper quadrant. It's nontenderand mobile. What is the ONE MOST LIKELY DISEASE?
questions.solution:
Fibroadenomas are the most common breast tumours found in adolescence and young women. Clinically, fibroadenomas are firm, nontender, highly mobile palpable lumps. It is important to remember that the most distinctive feature of fibroadenomas that distinguishes them from other breast lumps are the fact that they are highly mobile. In fact, some small lumps may slip away from the examining hand during palpation because they are extremely mobile, giving rise to their description “breast mice”.

Most fibroadenomas are found in the upper outer quadrant of the breast. They are thought to result from an increased sensitivity to oestrogen.

Diagnosis is usually made with a combination of clinical assessment, ultrasonography and fine needle aspiration cytology. Mammography- pop corn calcification

questions.text: A 42-year-old guy suffers from crampy stomach pain and rectal bleeding on a regular basis. Multiple hamartomatous polyps are discovered during a colonoscopy. Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is characterized by intestinal polyposis and melanin spots of the oral mucosa. Unlike the adenomatous polyps seen in familial polyposis, the lesions in this condition are hamartomas, which have no malignant potential. Surgery for symptomatic polyps involves polypectomy.

  • does not ↑risk of colorectal cancer
  • ↑ risk of S.I. malignancy
  • ↑ risk of

excess production of aldosterone d/t

  4. gain of H2O →

Gain of H2O = loss of H2O →So, no pedal edema

5. Cognitive dysfunction, ↑chances of type 1 DM

Investigation:

IOC - saline infusion test (best diagnostic yield) salt loading test

CONN's syndrome

  • then get PAC fitness → do surgery:U/Laparoscopic adrenalectomy →definitive treatment

B/L adrenal hyperplasia

questions.text: Which of the following signs are NOT appreciated in hypertensive retinopathy?
questions.solution:
Hypertensive Retinopathy

  • Changes occurring in retina due to uncontrolled elevated BP.
  • WHO defines HTN as BP > 140/90
    • Retinopathy → M/C
    • Choroidopathy
    • Neuropathy
  • 2 phases in Hypertensive retinopathy

Pathophysiology

Retinal blood vessels have 3 distinct features

  1. Absence of sympathetic nerve supply
  2. Autoregulation of blood flow
  3. Presence of blood retinal barrier

Classification

Modified Scheie’s classification

Grade 0 no changes
Grade 1 Barely detectable arterial narrowing
Grade 2 obvious arterial narrowing with focal iiregularities
Grade 3 Grade 2 + retinal hemorrhages / exudates
Grade 4

Grade 3 + disc swelling

Signs seen

  1. Copper wiring:- ALR widens and coppery colour
  2. Silver wiring:- Wall becomes opaque & no blood visible
  3. AV nicking:- (nicking means to cut) Or AV nipping

(Vein appears to stop abruptly)

Thickened artery nips (cuts), th vein into two as artery thickens & becomes less transparent

↓

Veins running under artery appears to be cut this is K/a AV nicking / AV nipping

Banking:

  • Vein twisted on distal side and widens
  • Because of the thickened artery present on the delicate vein as artery thickens
    • It compresses the vein
    • Vein appears twisted & widened
      • Vein appears to bet twisted & widened (K/a vein banking)

Simplified classification By Wong and Mitchell

  • Divides retinopathy in to 3 stages

Mild

1 or more of the following

  • Generalized arterioloar narrowing
  • Focal arteriolar narrowing
  • AV nicking

Moderate

1 or more of the following sisns

  • Retinal hemorrhages (dot, blot, flame shaped)
  • Cotton wool exudates
  • Hard exudates
  • Micro aneurysms

Acclerated

  • Moderateretinopathy + optic disc swelling

Retinal changes in Hypertensive Retinopathy

  • Haemorrhages
    • Dot & blot hemorrhages
    • Bleeding in inner retinal layers
    • Flame shaped hemorrhages
    • Bleeding in superficial retinal layers
  • Exudates
    • Hard exudates Lipid deposits on the retina
    • Soft exudates Cotton wool spots
  • Macular changes
    • Macular star

Blood and thunder sign is seen in central retinal vein occlusion.

questions.text: For the past six months, a 53-year-old lady has been experiencing vaginal dryness, hot flashes, and night sweats. Her most recent menstrual period was about a year ago. As part of her blood pressure treatment, she is currently using an ACE inhibitor. What is the SINGLE most effective treatment for her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Hormone replacement therapy like oestrogen and progestogen patches are indicated here as she is having menopausal symptoms. This systemic treatment can also alleviate symptoms of vaginal dryness.

A vaginal oestrogen cream or pessary would be appropriate if the patient only had symptoms of vaginal dryness without the other symptoms of menopause like hot flushes. In such cases, there is no need for a systemic treatment as topical treatment can alleviate symptoms.

Current evidence suggests that, the use of HRT is not associated with an increase in blood pressure and therefore HRT is not contraindicated in women with hypertension as long as the blood pressure can be controlled by antihypertensive medication. It is good practice to monitor the patient’s blood pressure 2 to 3 times in the first 6 months and then 6 monthly.

INDICATION OF HORMONE REPLACEMENT THERAPY

  • Vasomotor symptoms: hot flushes
  • Urogenital atrophy: vaginitis, urinary symptoms
  • Osteoporosis: prevention and treatment
  • Premature menopause: premature ovarian failure, oophorectomy, pelvic irradiation

Contraindications to hormone therapy use include

  1. Undiagnosed vaginal bleeding
  2. H/o Breast cancer
  3. H/O Endometrial Cancer
  4. Liver Dysfunction
  5. Thromboembolic Disease
  6. Fibroids
  7. Porphyria

  2. ptosis / diplopia
  3. DTR ↓↓

    • Dry mouth
    • impotence
  5. Repetitive nerve stimulation - to differentiate with myasthenia gravis

After RNS - ask patient to exercise which lead to increase Ach release at NMJ - leading to substantial increase of amplitude - Incremental response

Antibody is anti P/Q antibody against voltage sensitive Ca++ channels

questions.text: Which statement is NOT true for retinopathy of prematurity?

choices.text: Blindness can be prevented by early diagnosis and ablation of vascular premature retina with cryotherapy or photocoagulation
Occurs in premature infants due to late crying
Neovascularization follows fibroproliferation due to hypoxia

questions.solution:
RETINOPATHY OF PREMATURITY

Retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) is a bilateral proliferative retinopathy, occurring in premature infants with low birth weight who often have been exposed to high concentration of oxygen. Earlier this disease was known as retrolental fibroplasia.

Etiopathogenesis

Low birth weight and decreased gestational age are now considered the primary causative factors. Supplemental oxygen administration which was for a long time considered as the important causative factor is now considered only a risk factor. Based on the above facts, two important hypothesis are postulated to describe pathogenesis of disease:

  1. Classical theory postulates that owing to exposure to high concentration of oxygen, there occurs obliteration of premature retinal vessels. This is followed by neovascularisation and fibrous tissue proliferatiion which ultimately forms a retrolental mass.
  2. Spindle cell theory proposed recently postulates the induction of retinal and vitreal neovascularization by spindle cell insult in a premature retina.

Clinical features

The condition has been divided into active ROP and cicatricial ROP. Clinically the evolution of the active ROP has been divided into five stages (Fig. 11.16):

  • Stage 1: It is characterised by formation of a demarcation line seen at the edge of vessels, dividing the vascular from the avascular retina.
  • Stage 2: The line structure of stage 1 acquires a volume to form a ridge with height and width.
  • Stage 3: It is characterised by a ridge with extraretinal fibrovascular proliferation into the vitreous. This stage is further subdivided into mild, moderate and severe, depending on the amount of fibrovascular proliferation.
  • Stage 4a: It includes subtotal retinal detachment not involving the macula. It occurs as a result of exudation from incompetent blood vessels or traction from the fibrous (cicatricial) tissue.
  • Stage 4b: It includes subtotal retinal detachment involving the macula.
  • Stage 5: It is marked by total retinal detachment which is always funnel-shaped.

Screening and management

Treatment of well-established disease is unsatisfactory. Prophylaxis is thus very important. To prevent ROP, the premature newborns should not be placed in incubator with an O2 concentration of more than 30 percent and efforts should be made to avoid infection and attacks of apnoea. Further, a regular screening is very important.

All premature babies born at less than or equal to 32 weeks of gestational age and those weighing 1500 g or less should be screened for ROP. The first examination by indirect ophthalmosocpy should be done between 6 and 7 weeks post-natal age or 34 weeks post-conceptual age (whichever is earlier). The further line of action will depend upon the overall status of the eye as below:

  1. Mature retina is labelled when the vessels have reached within one disc diameter of both nasal and temporal ora-serrate. Infants with mature retina does not require further follow-up.
  2. Immature retina is labelled when the vessels are short of one disc diameter of the nasal or temporal ora but ROP is not developed yet. Such infants require further follow-up weekly.
  3. Retinopathy of prematurity When ROP is detected following measures should be taken:
  • Stage 1 and 2. Since spontaneous regression of disease occurs in 80 to 90% of cases, so only a weekly examination is recommended.
  • Stage 3, threshold disease should be treated by cryo or laser to prevent progression and to achieve regression.
  • Stage 4a. Scleral buckling is recommended in addition to cryo or laser therapy.
  • Stage 4b and 5, Vitrectomy needs to be carried out in this stage.

Prognosis is poor in stage 4 b and 5.

questions.text: A 5 year old female child presents to the emergency with a high grade fever, difficulty in breathing and refusal to eat which has progressively increased over 24 hours. On examination, she is drooling and prefers to sit with neck hyperextended. What should be the next step in management of this patient?

choices.text: Order a head and neck Xray
Reassure the patient and provide supportive management

questions.solution:
The 5 year old girl with acute symptoms like high grade fever, difficulty in breathing, dysphagia and tripod position ( sitting position with neck hyperextension ) points to epiglottitis. It is an acute inflammatory condition confined to supraglottic structures, i.e. epiglottis, aryepiglottic folds and arytenoids. There is marked oedema of these structures which may obstruct the airway. It is a serious condition and affects children of 2–7 years of age but can also affect adults. H. influenzae B is the most com- mon organism responsible for this condition in children. Onset of symptoms is abrupt with rapid progression. Sore throat and dysphagia are the common presenting symptoms in adults. Dyspnea and stridor are the common presenting symptoms in children. They are rapidly progressive and may prove fatal unless relieved. Fever may go up to 40°C. It is due to septicemia. Patient’s condition may rapidly deteriorate.

Treatment involves prompt hospitalization and intubation or tracheostomy to secure the airway and relieve the possible or impending respiratory obstruction. Antibiotics Ampicillin or third generation cephalosporin are effective against H. influenzae and are given by parenteral route (IM or IV) without waiting for results of throat swab and blood culture. Steroids like Hydrocortisone or dexamethasone is given in appropriate doses IM or IV.They relieve oedema and may obviate need for tracheostomy. Adequate hydration and humidified oxygen also helps.
