questions.text: Numerous pink umblicated papules on the genitals, thighs, and lower belly present in a 39-year-old guy. They are little, measuring only 1-3 mm in length. When pinching the papules, white material can be seen. He has been diagnosed as HIV positive. What is the ONE MOST LIKELY DISEASE?
questions.solution:
• Molluscum contagiosum (pox virus) are white or pink papules with an umblicated (depressed) central punctum. They may be found anywhere on the skin.
  • They resolve spontaneously but can take around 6 to 24 months.
  • If squeezed, they produce a cheesy material.
  • They usually affect children.
  • They are also especially seen in patients with decreased immunity and so if a patient presents with extensive pink umblicated papules, consider AIDS.
  • Management

First line

  • Caustic destruction: cantharidin, trichloroacetic acid, diluted liquefied phenol
  • Irritant: salicylic acid, adapalene, nitric oxide cream, potassium hydroxide, benzoyl peroxide, lemon myrtle oil, tea tree oil
  • Surgical irritation

Second line

  • Immunological: diphencyprone, imiquimod, interferon, cimetidine, intralesionalimmunotherapy
  • Surgical removal

Third line

  • Cidofovir
  • Paclitaxel
  • The antiviral agentcidofovir- effectively resolve molluscum lesions (used either intravenously or topically as a ("3% ointment or cream).It should be considered for treating extensive lesions in, for example, immuno? incompetentpatients where eradication has proved difficult with standard treatment regimens

questions.text: A four-week-old female infant goes to the ER with vomiting after each feeding. The vomiting was projectile and non-bilious, according to the mother.In addition, the child is constipated..Palpation of the abdomen reveals a right sided olive sized mass. What is the one most appropriate next step of action?
questions.solution:
• This is a common symptom of pyloric stenosis. There will be an electrolyte imbalance because the youngster is vomiting a lot. Hypokalemia may be present, and it must be treated right away.
  • In actuality, while waiting for the serum potassium readings, blood would be drawn and an abdominal ultrasound scheduled. The exam writers, on the other hand, want you to consider which is the most important, given the stem. Pay attention to the question's concluding line. If the inquiry is about the NEXT STEP, serum potassium levels would be a good place to start. Abdominal ultrasound would be the NEXT STEP IN DIAGNOSING the disease if the inquiry was about the NEXT STEP IN DIAGNOSING the ailment. · Following the blood draw, intravenous fluid should be administered.
  • Presentation:- Non-bilious projectile vomiting
    • Age range: 2 to 6 weeks
    • Abdominal mass the size of an olive
    • Despite the continual vomiting, the child will feel hungry and desire to eat.
  • Diagnosis:- Ultrasound of the abdomen
  • Treatment:
    • Metabolic alkalosis – correct electrolyte imbalance + hydration
    • After that, paediatric surgery (pyloromyotomy) and a nasogastric tube are recommended.

questions.text: A thick creamy brown discharge is emerging from the left nipple of a 50-year-old smoker. For the past two weeks, it has been going on. For the past few months, she's had soreness in her left breast. On examination, she has a palpable subareolar mass on her left breast with nipple retraction. There are no lymph nodes that can be felt. Her body temperature is 37.1 degrees Celsius. What is the ONE MOST LIKELY DISEASE?
questions.solution:
Duct ectasia refers to dilatation of the large and intermediate breast ducts and it is suggested by a green or brown nipple discharge. The subareolar mammary ducts become chronically inflamed, dilated and scarred. The first clue given is that she is a smoker. Duct ectasia is associated with smoking. The other options in this question are less likely.

Breast abscess→ is suggested by a fluctuant lump, hot and tender, acute presentation often in puerperium, chronic after antibiotics

Duct papilloma→ is suggested by bleeding from nipple

Ductal fistula (Mammillary fistula)→ is an abnormal communication between a mammary duct and the skin surface, usually near the areola and is suggested by discharge from a para-areolar region

DUCT ECTASIA (PERIDUCTAL MASTITIS)

  • Dilatation of multiple ducts, Associated withperiductal inflammation
  • Most common age- above 50 years
  • Most common presenting feature:nipple discharge(Greenish)
  • Discharge in duct ectasia : Greenish/serous/bloody

Management

  • Treatment of duct ectasia isHadfield's operation.

HADFIELD's OPERATION -A periareolar incision is made and a cone of tissue is removed with its apex just deep to the surface of the nipple and its base on the pectoral fascia.

Nipple Dishcarge

bloody Nipple discharge Serous nipple discharge Greenish, Blackish, Grumous or Pultaceous discharge
  • Duct papilloma (MC)
    • Carcinoma
    • Duct ectasia
  • Fibrocystic disease(MC)
    • carcinoma
    • duct ectasia
  • Duct ectasia
    • any kind of nipple discharge is possible for duct ectasia

Duct ectasia / periductal mastitis Duct papilloma
Dilatation of breast ducts with periductal inflammation solitary intraductal papillomas are true polyps of epithelial lined breast ducts
more common in smokers most often located close to the areola
greenish dishcrage not associated with an increased risk of breast cancer
chronic indurated mass may from beneath the aerola which mimics a cracinoma bloody nipple discharge if located close to nipple
Hadfield's operation (excision of all of the major ducts) microdochectomy (Tennis racquet incision) is the excision of involved duct done in duct papilloma

questions.text: A 26-year-old lady with regular periods and her 28-year-old partner visit their Doctor for primary infertility. She and her husband have been attempting to conceive for over two years but have been unsuccessful. Her menstrual cycle is 28 days long. Her body mass index (BMI) is 23. What is the ONE MOST APPROPRIATE EXAMINATION to see whether she's ovulating?

choices.text: Day 2 follicular stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH)

questions.solution:
• Day 21 progesterone which is the mid-luteal progesterone level is used to assess ovulation. If this is low, it may need repeating, as ovulation does not occur every month. ·
  • FSH and LH should be measured if there is menstrual irregularity: High levels may suggest poor ovarian function. A comparatively high LH level relative to FSH level can occur in PCOS. In reality, we would obtain FSH, LH and mid-luteal progesterone levels.
  • Basal body temperature charts are not recommended to predict ovulation, as they are unreliable.

Primary diagnostic steps in the workup of the infertile couple include

  • Documentation of ovulation by USG or mid-luteal phase serum progesterone ( Serum progesterone 7 days prior to expected next period. Meaning day 21 of a28 day cycle. However, this day will need to be adjusted for different lengths of cycle)
  • Semen analysis
  • Hysterosalpingogram.
    • HSG is performed in the mid-follicular phase (day 8 or 9), in order to evaluate the fallopian tubes and the contour of the uterine cavity. It should not be done while the patient is menstruating or after ovulation has occurred and in the premenstrual phase as the patient might be pregnant.

questions.text: Parents took their 14-year-old son to the hospital because of a painful swelling in his neck. Physical examination indicated a swelling in the midline of his neck, immediately in front of the trachea, below the hyoid bone. It was also discovered that the mass is a palpable, non-tender, fluid-filled lump that travels upwards when swallowed and when the tongue protrudes. Its diameter was estimated to be around 1.5 cm. The patient was suspected of having a thyroglossal cyst after a comprehensive history and physical examination. What is the ONE MOST APPROPRIATE Investigation TO CONDUCT?
questions.solution:
• A thyroglossal cyst is a fibroid cyst that forms from a persistent thyroglossal duct. It usually presents as an asymptomatic fluid-filled midline neck mass below the level of the hyoid bone. It is benign and results from an incomplete closure of the thyroid’s migration path during fetal development.
  • It typically presents as a painless anterior midline neck mass and is found most often in childhood or adolescence. This is a very important point to remember. Thyroglossal cyst accounts for around 75% of midline masses in children. Thyroglossal cysts are congenital, however, the diagnosis can be made at any age with most of them diagnosed before 10 years of age.

How do you diagnose a thyroglossal cyst?

  • Ultrasound of the cyst is a sensible next step and is performed to distinguish a solid cyst from fluid-filled components and to visualize the degree of the mass as well as its surrounding tissues. It is the first line imaging study and ultrasound alone can be sufficient to conform the diagnosis in majority of cases.
  • MRI or CT are used when malignancy is suspected but are not used routinely unless there is a large cyst.
  • Thyroid scan with technitium 99m(Tc-99m) can be used to determine if there are any ectopic thyroid tissue. Remember, the wall of a thyroglossal duct cyst is the second most common site for ectopic thyroid tissue.
  • Fine needle aspiration cytology is performed in order to establish the character of the cells inside the cyst. However, given the low incidence of carcinoma in thyroid cyst especially in children, preoperative biopsy of thyroglossal cyst is not cost effective and is not recommended.

Treatment:Sistrunk operation –En bloc excision of central part of hyoid bone along with the cyst to minimise recurrence

questions.text: A 32-week-pregnant 20-year-old primiparous woman goes to the maternity evaluation centre with a history of painless vaginal bleeding after intercourse. She is not scheduled at your current hospital, but has been referred to the nearest hospital for evaluation. She claims that her pregnancy has gone smoothly and that she has been seeing her midwife in the community. On examination, the uterus is soft and relaxed, with a fundal height of 32 cm. CTG is within typical limits. Her heart rate is 112 beats per minute, her blood pressure is 94/60 mmHg, and her breathing rate is 26 breaths per minute. What is the ONE MOST LIKELY DISEASE?
questions.solution:
Painless vaginal bleeding without abdominal pain should raise suspicion of placenta praevia.

The painless bleeding seen in placenta praevia may occur without warning or after intercourse. This is one reason obstetricians advise women with placenta praevia not to have intercourse.

Placenta praevia

Placenta praevia describes a placenta lying wholly or partly in the lower uterinesegment.This is common early in the pregnancy, but is most often not associated with bleeding.

The key clinical feature is painless bleeding after 24 weeks of gestation.

Risk factors

  • previous placenta praevia
  • multiple pregnancies

Clinical features

  • Painless vaginal bleed
  • uterus not tender
  • lie and presentation may be abnormal
  • fetal heart usually normal

The painless late-pregnancy bleeding may occur during rest or activity, suddenlyand without warning. It may be preceded by trauma, coitus, or pelvic examination. A digital vaginal examination should not be performed. However, a speculum or a transvaginal probe can safely be used in placenta praevia.

Diagnosis

  • This is based on the presence of painless late-trimester vaginal bleeding with anobstetric ultrasound showing placental implantation over the lower uterine segment.
  • A transvaginal ultrasound is preferred over abdominal ultrasound for detection ofplacenta praevia.

management -

Mcafee and Johnson Regimen-It is a regimen used for placenta previa when pregnancy is <34 weeks(lungs are not maturated) and there is not active bleeding.

In it, following is done:

  1. Resuscitation
  2. Steroids for fetal lung maturity
  3. Sedation
  4. Maternal and fetal monitoring
  • At 38 weeks, there is no need for conservative management since maturity is already achieved. The best management is a Cesarean section here

# If the same patient presented at less than 36 weeks, the answer would be wait and watch.

# If there was fetal distress at any stage after 28 weeks with APH, the answer would be LSCS

# If there was maternal hemodynamic instability, the answer would be blood and IV fluids, followed by emergency LSCS

questions.text: A 44-year-old man has a single, shining red nodule that has been bothering him. For months, this growth had been growing on his nose. It has a central depression and is solid. It measures 0.7 cm in length. What is the ONE MOST LIKELY DISEASE?
questions.solution:
• The clues for basal cell carcinoma in the exam are descriptions of a pearly white umbilicated ulcer with central depression anywhere in the face with rolled edges or inverted edge.
  • BASAL CELL CARCINOMA
  • Basal cell carcinomas (BCCs) are slow-growing, locally invasive malignant epidermal skin tumours
  • Risk factors:
    • Genetic predisposition
    • Exposure to ultraviolet (UV) radiation
  • Presentation:
    • The sun-exposed areas of the head and neck are the most commonly involved sites
    • Early lesions are often small, translucent or pearly and have raised areas with telangiectasia
    • Indurated edge and ulcerated centre

Rxof BCC

  • Electro-desiccation and curettage (ED&C)is most commonly employed method for superficial, minimally invasive nodular BCCs and low-risk tumors.
  • Wide local excision is selected for invasive, ill-defined, and more aggressive sub types of tumors, or for cosmetic reasons.
  • Mohs micrographic surgery (MMS), a specialized type of surgical excision, best method for tumor removal while preserving uninvolved tissue

questions.text:
Which of the following are the correct statements?

Bohlers angle is angle between joint and imaginary line along calcaneal tuberosity.
Q angle increases in patellar dislocation.
Insall Salvati Ratio is a ratio between ligamentum patellae to patellar length.
Angle of Gissaine decreases in the fracture of calcaneum.
questions.solution:
Angles in Orthopaedics:

  • Bohlers Angle
    • Angle between joint and imaginary line along the calcaneal tuberosity
    • angle is 20-40 degree further lowers in fracture calcaneum
    • Mnemonic: Bohler's - lowers
  • Angle of Gissaine
    • Angle along the joint surface value of angle is 95-105 degree further gains angle in the fracture calcaneum
    • Gissaine - Gains

  • Q - Angle (Q-Quadriceps)
    • It is the angle between a line that starts from ASIS to mid-point of patella and a line that joins tibial tuebrosity to the mid-point of patella and vector drawn up.
    • ↑ ↑ Q- Angle → Patellar subluxation / Dislocation (lateral pull)

  • Insall Salvati Ratio = Ligamentum patellae / Patellar length
    • <0.8 = Patella Baja
    • >1.2 Patella Alta

chances of dislocation is higher with patella Alta

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is linked to the highest rate of hepatitis after surgery?
questions.solution:
There are two distinct types of hepatic injury with clinical exposure of halothane.

Subclinical hepatotoxicity-occurs in 20% of adults who receive halothane which is characterized by mild postoperative elevation of AST and ALT but is reversible and innocuous. Anaerobic halothane reduction by CYP2A6 to a 2-chloro-1,1,1 triflouroethyl radical mediates this mild hepatic injury.

Fulminant hepatitis, commonly known asHalothane hepatitis(rare 1 in 5000-35000 administrations in adults) but is fatal in between 50-75% cases. This is characterized by elevated ALT, AST, bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase levels and massive hepatic necrosis.

  • Halothane hepatitis is a hypersensitivity reaction associated with oxidative metabolism of halothane.
  • It is due to antibodies against highly reactive trifluoroacetyl chloride which is a oxidative metabolite of halothane react with nearby liver proteins. Hepatic damage is due to immune response against the modified protein which acts as a neoantigen.
  • Risk factors for halothane hepatitis:
    • Prior exposure to halaothane or other volatile agents
    • Multiple exposures to halothane at short intervals
    • middle-aged obese women – because halothane undergo extensive metabolism in obese patients
    • familial predisposition to halothane
  • The liver in halothane hepatitis shows centrilobular necrosis.
  • Fever, rash, arthralgia, eosinophilia are clinical features suggestive of immune reactivity
  • Other volatile agents such as enflurane, isoflurane and desflurane are also associated with fulminant hepatic necrosis but incidence is rare and mechanism of toxicity is same as that of halothane(highly reactive intermediary metabolites covalently modify hepatic proteins)
  • Cases of hepatitis and rapid death are associated with sevoflurane anaesthesia but there was no evidence of immune mediated mechanism

questions.text: A 64-year-old man was discovered to have grade 2 haemorrhoids during a regular colonoscopy for colorectal cancer screening. He claims that the haemorrhoids do not produce any pain or rectal bleeding when questioned after the treatment. What is the ONE MOST LIKELY management method?
questions.solution:
A grade 2 haemorrhoids without bleeding or pain does not need to be treated unless they bother the patient.

  • Hemorrhoids
    • are normal anatomcial cushions
    • made of
  • venules
  • arterioles
  • smooth muscle fibers
  • elastic tissues

location of hemorrhoids

  • 3'o clock
  • 7'o clock
  • 11'o clock

pathophysiology

  • on constipation due to excessive straining

↓

Abnormal descent of anatomical cushions

↓

Injury by hard fecal matter

↓

Bleeding PR

    • MC cause of bleeding PR- hemorrhoids
    • mc cause of significant lower GI bleed - colonic diverticula
    • mc cause of occult lower GI bleed - angiodysplasia / vascular ectasia
  • clinical presentation
    • painless bleeding
    • amount of bleeding - 3 to 5 ml to a max of 10 ml
  • diagnosis
    • they cannot be palpated, therefore hemorrhoids cannot be diagnosed by DRE
    • diagnosis of hemorrhoids - by proctoscopy
Internal Hemorrhoids External Hemorrhoids
location - below dentate line (pain sensitive region)
location - above dentate line (pain insensitive region) painful bleeding
painless bleeding aka 5 - days painful self-curing lesion
treatment - depends on the degree recurrent thrombosis in external hemorrhoids leads to semi-RIPE black currant
treatment - excision

Internal haemorrhiods can be classified into 4 grades

  • Grade I: No prolapse out of anal canal, just prominent blood vessels
  • Grade II: Prolapse seen when strains but spontaneously reduces and returns
  • Grade III: Prolapse seen when strains requiring manual reduction
  • Grade IV: Prolapse seen and cannot be manually reduced

Treatment

First degree hemorrhoids

  • Dietary modification
  • Stool softener
  • High fiber diet

First degree, second degree and selected patients of third degree

  • Banding
  • Sclerotherapy (5% phenol in almond oil)
  • Both banding and sclerotherapy are very cheap and effective
  • In banding→ Rubber band is applied over the hemorrhoids. After 48 hours, hemorrhoids are sloughed off because of ischemia and the lesion heals with fibrosis.

Rest of third-degree patients and fourth degree patients-Hemorrhoidectomy

  • MiIligan – Morgan open Hemorrhoidectomy
  • Longo’s Stapler hemorrhoidectomy ( most preferred method )

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman with many sexual partners has been complaining for 18 months of non-cyclical intermittent lower abdomen pain, profound dyspareunia, and monthly irregularities. On vaginal examination, she has cervical excitement and both adnexae are sensitive. She doesn't have any relevant medical history. Which of the following is the ONE MOST LIKELY CAUSE OF HER SYMPTOMS?
questions.solution:
Multiple sexual partners are a risk factor for pelvic inflammatory disease. Women other age group (<25 years old) are of greater risk for pelvic inflammatory disease as they are more sexually active during this period.

Other options are less likely because:

Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome → is a complication of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).Usually presents with an acute onset of right upper quadrant (RUQ) abdominal pain aggravated by breathing, or coughing. This pain may be referred to the right shoulder

Cervicitis → Presents with discharge. Do not get confused between cervicitis and PID.Infection at the cervix can eventually ascend to cause PID. But if the infection is purelyat the cervix, they will not present with menstrual irregularities and lower abdominalpain as the infection has not ascended to involve the uterus, fallopian tubes, andovaries.

Asherman syndrome → are adhesions of the endometrium often associated withdilation and curettage of the intrauterine cavity. It results in infertility. Often, theyexperience menstrual irregularities. But in this question there is no relevant pastmedical history meaning she did not have any dilation and curettage thus this option isvery unlikely.

PELVIC INFLAMMATORY DISEASE (PID)

Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) is a term used to describe infection and inflammation of the female pelvic organs including the uterus, fallopian tubes, ovaries and the surrounding peritoneum. Most commonly caused by ascending infection from the endocervix.

  • Causative organisms
  • Chlamydia trachomatis - the most common cause
  • Neisseriagonorrhoeae
  • Risk factors for PID
    • Age <25
    • Previous STIs
    • New sexual partner/multiple sexual partners
    • Uterine instrumentation such as surgical termination of pregnancy
    • Intrauterine contraceptive devices
    • Post-partumendometritis
  • Features
    • lower abdominal pain
    • fever
    • deep dyspareunia
    • dysuria and menstrual irregularities may occur
    • vaginal or cervical discharge
    • cervical excitation
    • Abnormal vaginal bleeding (intermenstrual, postcoital)
  • Investigation
    • screen for Chlamydia and Gonorrhoea Management- Antibiotics

questions.text: Which of the following statements are NOT true about acute suppurative otitis media?

choices.text: Group A Beta-hemolytic streptococcus is the most common causative organism in acute otitis media
The cart-wheel appearance of tympanic membrane is seen in the stage of pre-suppuration
The Rinne hearing test in acute otitis media show that bone conduction is better than air conduction
In infants and young children, the angle of eustachian tube is more acute as compared to adults which explains the increase acute otitis media cases in this age group

questions.solution:
It is an acute inflammation of middle ear by pyogenic organisms. Typically, the disease follows viral infection of upper respiratory tract but soon the pyogenic organisms invade the middle ear. Infection via eustachian tube is the most common route and any anatomic or functional obstruction to it can cause AOM. Infection travels via the lumen of the tube or along subepithelial peritubal lymphatics.

It is more common especially in infants and children of lower socioeconomic group. Eustachian tube in infants and young children is shorter, wider and more horizontal and thus may account for higher incidence of infections in this age group. Breast or bottle feeding in a young infant in horizontal position may force fluids through the tube into the middle ear and hence the need to keep the infant propped up with head a little higher.

Most common organisms in infants and young children are Streptococcus pneumoniae (30%), Haemophilus influenzae (20%) and Moraxella catarrhalis (12%). Group A streptococcus (Streptococcus pyogenes) is not the most common cause.

The cart wheel appearance of tympanic membrane is seen in presuppuration phase. To begin with, there is congestion of pars tensa. Leash of blood vessels appear along the handle of malleus and at the periphery of tympanic membrane imparting it a cart-wheel appearance. Later, whole of tympanic membrane including pars flaccida becomes uniformly red.

In Rinne test, a vibrating tuning fork is placed on the patient’s mastoid and when he stops hearing, it is brought beside the meatus. If he still hears, AC is more than BC. Alternatively, the patient is asked to compare the loudness of sound heard through air and bone conduction. Rinne test is called positive when AC is longer or louder than BC. It is seen in normal persons or those having sensorineural deafness. A negative Rinne (BC > AC) is seen in conductive deafness. Since acute suppurative otitis media involves middle ear which is responsible for conduction of sound, therefore tuning fork tests will again show conductive type of hearing loss.

questions.text: Several instances of palpitations, sweating, nausea, and intense terror have occurred in a 23-year-old lady. She was awoken from a nap once and had the terrifying thought that she was going insane. She has no prior psychiatric medical history and is not currently taking any medications. What is the ONE MOST LIKELY DISEASE?
questions.solution:
• It is quite difficult to differentiate generalized anxiety disorder with panic disorder.People with generalized anxiety disorder feel anxious most days and often struggle to remember the last time they felt relaxed. As soon as one anxious thought is resolved, another may appear about a different issue. Panic disorder, however is where you have recurring and regular panic attacks, often for no apparent reason similar to this stem where she had several sudden onset episodes of panic.

Panic disorder

  • Panic disorder is classified as having 2 recurrent panic attacks, which are not secondary to substance misuse, medical conditions, or another psychiatric disorder. Frequency of occurrence may vary from many attacks a day to only a few a year. Usually patients have a persistent worry about having another attack or consequences of the attack.
  • Symptoms/signs
    • Physical symptoms/signs related to autonomic arousal (e.g. tremor,tachycardia, tachypnoea, hypertension, sweating)
    • Concerns of death from cardiac or respiratory problems may be a major focus, leading to patients presenting (often repeatedly) to emergency medical services.

questions.text: 33-year-old woman presents with severe colickypain in her rt. iliac fossa. The pain is excruciating and has been getting worse over the previous few hours. There is a radiation of the pain to her pelvis and back . Since the discomfort began, she has been vomiting and feeling nauseated. On examination, a painful, movable lump is felt in the right iliac fossa. What is the ONE MOST LIKELY DISEASE?
questions.solution:
• The likely diagnosis here is ovarian torsion. Although ovarian torsion cannot be diagnosed clinically as it is often diagnosed in theatre during a laparoscopy, the question writers want you to consider ovarian torsion as part of your differential diagnosis as it is one of the important gynaecologic emergencies. It is quite rare and only accounts for about 3% of gynaecologic emergencies however it is important to consider it especially given that this patient has a tender mobile mass at the right iliac fossa.
  • In clinical practice, appendicitis would also be part of your differential. If there was a history of an ovarian mass or if a ultrasound pelvis was done which found an ovarian mass, then the surgeons would refer her to the gynaecology team to rule out an ovarian torsion.
  • Ovarian torsion presents with sudden onset of sharp, unilateral lower abdominal pain often with nausea and vomiting.
  • In the reproductive years, regular growth of large corpus luteal cysts are a risk factor for rotation. Basically, any enlargement of the ovary is a risk factor towards an ovarian torsion.
  • The definitive diagnosis is often made in the theatre as ovarian torsion is difficult to diagnose accurately and operation is often performed before the diagnosis is made.

questions.text: The lower pole of the parotid gland is swollen in a 68-year-old male. For the past seven years, this bulge has been slowly increasing. The parotid gland has a solid consistency when examined. What is the ONE MOST LIKELY DIAGNOSE?
questions.solution:
Benign mixed parotid tumor (pleomorphic adenoma) is slow growing and lobular, firm and capsulated and accounts for approximately 50% of parotid tumor.

PLEOMORPHIC ADENOMA

  • It isMC benign salivary gland tumor and MC tumor of major salivary glands.
  • MC site is parotid tail (superficial lobe)
  • Known asmixed tumoras it iscomposed of both epithelial & mesenchymal components
  • Encapsulated but sends pseudopodia (finger-like projections) into surrounding glands, enucleation is not done to avoid recurrence.
  • Slow-growing and asymptomatic , Solitory , Painless, Usually mobile , Firm single nodular mass
  • Pleomorphic adenoma is unicentric but recurrences are multicentric
  • Usually does not involve the facial nerve.
  • FNAC is diagnostic
  • TREATMENTisSuperficial parotidectomy (Patey’s operation)

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman with vaginal spotting and slight left-sided stomach pain presents to the Early Pregnancy Unit. Her last period was eight weeks ago. A pregnancy test at the doctor's office came back positive. A transvaginal ultrasound scan was performed on her and was found to be 'inconclusive.' Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) levels in the blood are 1400 IU/litre. What is the most likely SINGLE diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The diagnosis here is ectopic pregnancy. The first clue here is the gestational age → 8weeks. Ectopic pregnancies would usually present around 6-8 weeks from start of last period as it is then that they are large enough to stretch the fallopian tubes thus causing pain. The stretching of the fallopian tubes is also the reason why they may sometimes experience cervical motion tenderness on a vaginal examination.
  • The second clue here is the unilateral abdominal pain. This gives us a clue that the pathology is towards one side rather than in the middle

Ectopic pregnancy

  • Is one in which the fertilized ovum is implanted & develops outside the normal endometrial cavity

Site

  • Tubal (most common)
  • Ovarian
  • Abdominal
  • Cervical

Common cause

  • Salpingitis
  • PID
  • Contraception failure (IUCD )
  • Tubal ligation

Presentation

  • Abdominal pain
  • Amenorrhea
  • Vaginal bleeding

Diagnosis

  • hCG ( either in urine or serum ): to check doubling titres
  • Transvaginalsonography; usual test to diagnose an ectopic pregnancy in the OPD
  • Laparoscopy (confirmation) best test: This of course is not the first test to be done for the diagnosis. This is mostly done when the clinical and USG suspicion is almost sure and a laparoscopy hence is diagnostic as well as therapeutic intervention.

Treatment

  • Surgical or medical

Medical management (methotrexate) is the treatment of choice for an ectopic pregnancy whenever the required criteria are fulfilled-

  1. Patient should be hemodynamically stable (unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy).
  2. Foetal cardiac activity absent (presence of cardiac activity is a relative contraindication).
  3. β-hCG levels <5,000 mIU/mL (levels > 5,000 mIU/mL is a relative contraindication).
  4. Gestational sac diameter <4 cm.
  5. Free fluid in POD <100 mL
  • Surgery could be done either by laparoscopy or laparotomy, either salpingotomy or salpingectomy
  • If haemodynamically stable → Laparoscopic salpingectomy or salpingostomy
  • If haemodynamically unstable → Laparotomy (open salpingectomy or salpingostomy)

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman is hospitalized because of shortness of breath on exertion, abdominal distention, and a 12 kg weight loss in the past three months. She has massive ascites on abdominal examination. Considering her serum albumin is 2.8 g/dl and her ascitic fluid albumin measures 2.2 g/dl, what is the most likely cause of the ascites in the patient?
questions.solution:
The differential diagnosis of ascites can be narrowed down by calculating the serum-ascites albumin gradient (SAAG), which is equal to the serum albumin value minus the ascitic fluid albumin value (not the ratio of the two). A SAAG value >1.1 g/dL is known as high albumin-gradient ascitic fluid and indicates portal hypertension, while a value < 1.1 g/dL is known as low albumin-gradient ascitic fluid and indicates that the patient does not have portal hypertension.

Clinical conditions associated with high SAAG (>1.1 g/dL) include congestive heart failure, cirrhosis, and alcoholic hepatitis. Conditions associated with low (< 1.1 g/dL) albumin gradient include peritoneal carcinomatosis, peritoneal tuberculosis, nephrotic syndrome, pancreatitis, and serositis.

This patient has a SAAG of 0.6 g/dL (2.8 minus 2.2), which indicates non portal hypertensive etiology of her ascites.

questions.text: The chief source of X-ray generation in radiology is-
questions.solution:
Bremsstrahlung radiation / Braking radiation

  • chief source of x-ray generation in conventional radiography
  • leads to generation of continuous spectrum of varying energies of x-ray

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman appears with a very strongfoul-smelling vaginal discharge. What organism(s) could be responsible for this symptom?
questions.solution:
• Bacterial vaginosis and Trichomonas vaginalis can give foul smelling discharge.
  • In bacterial vaginosis the vaginal discharge is grey-white and has a “fishy” smell.
  • In trichomonas vaginalis, it can be a greenish and frothy along with vulvovaginitis i.e. strawberry cervix.
  • The discharge of Chlamydia and Gonorrhea is not usually foul smelling.
  • Since Trichomoniasis is not present among the available choices, Gardnerella is the answer.

Bacteria Vaginosis

  • MC Vaginitis
  • Hemophilusvaginalis aka Gardenellavaginalis
  • Fishy vaginal odor,
  • Vaginal secretions are gray and thinly coat the vaginal walls
  • Microscopy:-Clue cells-Vaginal epithelium with embeded bacteria
  • No pruritus
  • The Whiff test- The addition of KOH to the vaginal secretions releases a amine like odor.
  • Amsel's criteria is used for diagnosis
  • Treatment:
    • Metronidazole
    • Treat the woman(No sexual transmission)

questions.text: Bone anchored hearing aid is indicated for patients with-

choices.text: Chronic ear discharge, not amenable to treatment

questions.solution:
Bone-anchored hearing aid is a type of hearing aid which is based on the principle of bone conduction. It is primarily suited to people who have conductive hearing loss, unilateral hearing loss and those with mixed hearing loss who cannot otherwise wear “in the ear” or “behind the ear” hearing aids. Bone-anchored hearing aids use a surgically implanted abutment to transmit sound by direct conduction through bone to the cochlea, bypassing the external auditory canal and middle ear.

Bone-anchored hearing aids can be used in:

  1. People who have chronic inflammation or infection of the ear canal and cannot wear standard "in the ear" air conduction hearing aids.
  2. Children with malformed or absent outer ear and ear canals as in microtia or canal atresia.
  3. Single-sided deafness – In the past, the contralateral; routing of signal (CROS) was the only available option for rehabilitation in single-sided deafness. Poor performance and aesthetic considerations limited the use of CROS aids. The BAHA is fixed on in the deaf side and collects sound waves to transmit to healthy cochlea of the other side. This process eliminates the head-shadow effect and allows for hearing from both sides of the head. The BAHA substantially improves speech recognition in quiet and in noise compared with the CROS aids.

questions.text: A patient who had three laparotomies over the course of fouryears presented to the hospitalwith bulky, foul-smelling faeces. There was a kidney stone and a gallstone on the ultrasonography abdomen. Which of the following statements concerning this condition is incorrect?

choices.text: Hypogastrinemia is linked to this condition
Megaloblastic anaemia is linked to this condition
The Bianchi technique is carried out
TPN is used to manage the majority of patients in the early post-operative period

questions.solution:
• Length of S.I — 600 cm
  • Length < 200 — SBS.

SHORT BOWEL SYNDROME

  • Malabsorptive condition that arises secondary to removal of significant segments of the small intestine.
  • Most common cause are Mesenteric infarction, crohn's disease, tumours, radiation enteritis
  • It usually appears when there is less than 200 cm of small bowel
  • The clinical hallmarks include diarrhea, fluid and electrolyte deficiency

Changes seen in Terminal Ileal Resection

  • Unabsorbed fatty acids bind with calcium-Increased concentration of free oxalates (oxalates bind with calcium normally and therefore escape without intestinal absorption)-Free oxalates are absorbed- Oxalate kidney stones
  • Vitamin B12 Malabsorption- Megaloblastic anemia
  • Hypergastrinemia - as gastrin catabolism occurs in short bowel
  • Bile salts Malabsorption-watery diarrhea
  • Decreased bile salts in the bile-
    • Cholesterol gall stones
    • Steatorrhea and Malabsorption of fat soluble vitamins

Mx:

  • Most patients are managed by TPN in early post-operative period
  • Antisecretory and anti motility agents may be used
  • Non transplant surgical therapies
    • BIANCHI Procedure - Longitudinal intestinal lengthening & Tailoring (LILT)
    • STEP - serial transverse enteroplasty procedure

questions.text: A 60-year-old guy is having trouble swallowing. He has foul breath and regurgitates meals. Recently, he's been coughing a lot. He's lost some weight in the last few months and is worried about oesophageal cancer. What is the ONE MOST APPROPRIATE FIRST Investigation?
questions.solution:
The bad breath and regurgitation of food points towards a pharyngeal pouch. Loss ofweight can also occur in pharyngeal pouch. The first step in investigation would be abarium swallow and not an endoscopy. Performing an endoscopy in a patient with pharyngeal pouch could lead to a perforation.

zenker's diverticulum / cricopharyngeal achalasia

  • most common esophageal diverticulum
  • usually seen in patients over 50 years
  • it is found hemiating from Killian's triangle, between thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus muscle
  • most common symptom is intermittent dysphagia
  • undigested food is regurgitated into the mouth, especially when the patient is in the recumbent position
  • swelling of the neck, gurgling noise after eating, halitosis, nagging cough, excessive salivation, retrosternal pain and a sour metallic taste in the mouth are common symptoms
  • most serious complication from an untreated Zenker's diverticulum is aspiration pneumonia or lung abscess
  • diagnosis is made by barium esophagram
  • at the level of cricothyroid cartilage, diverticulum can be seen filled with barium resting posteriorly alongside the esophagus (cricopharyngeal bar)
  • surgical or endoscopic repair is the gold standard of treatment

questions.text:
A 55 year old female presented with chest pain at rest and diaphoresis. She recently lost her husband to COVID pneumonia a week ago. Her ECG showed the following

She is diagnosed with Takotsubo cardiomyopathy and started with the treatment. Which of the following statements are true about Takotsubo cardiomyopathy?

choices.text: TOMB STONE PATTERN / Pardee sign: Seen in V2-V6 leads
It differs from MI as it shows normal coronary angiogram
Dobutamine is not given in treatment of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy

questions.solution:
TAKOTSUB CARDIOMYOPATHY

TTCM is also called broken heart syndrome and occurs due to catecholamine toxicity

  • occur in patient who had life threatening stress. E.g. earthquake, death of loved one.

Work up

1. ECG:

TOMB STONE pattern / Pardee sign: seen in V2-V6 leads (suggestive of extensive anterior wall MI, due to thrombus in left main coronary artery).

2. TROP I: 0.08mg/dl (doubling of baseline values)

3. Cath lab -Coronary angiography normal - Primary PCI: Abandoned

4. ECHO: Alteration of LV shape

Rx:

Treat as case of cardiogenic shock - IABP (intra-aortic balloon pump)

    • ACEI
    • beta blockers
  • causative agent - catecholamine therefore dopamine, dobutamine should not be given

Must know points for TTCM

  1. Acute onset cardiomyopathy
  2. Improvement on occurs gradually
  3. Mimics STEMI
  4. Cath Lab: Normal angiography
  5. It is differential diagnosis of STEMI and diagnosis is made in cath lab due to normal coronary angiogram.

questions.text:
Which of the following clinical manifestations with raised calcium ?

Nephrocalcinosis
Myxedema
Calcinosis cutis
Diarrhea
Psychosis
questions.solution:
RAISE OF CALCIUM BITS MANIFESTATIONS:

1. 11-12 mg% > Nephrocalcinosis

Renal Colic:

  • Presents as Plank pain going towards umbilicus .
  • A/W multiple hospitalizations d/t recurrent vomiting episodes caused by pylorospasm [as a result of Renogastric Reflex]
    • Constipation → d/t spasm of sphincters of gut →may present with abdominal pain

2. 12-13 mg%

  • Calcinosis cutis [Ca+2 deposited in skin of the pt]
  • Pseudo-hypertension [HTN d/t hardening of blood vessels]
  • Psychosis (Moaning Et groaning)
  • 2 degreeParkinsonism Edit calcification of basal ganglia] Bradykinesia / Rigidity

3. 13-14 mg% and higher → Systolic arrest incidence rises

Myxedema is a generalized nonpitting edema GAGs in interstitial spaces which increase osmotic pressure causing water retention; seen in hypothyroidism.

questions.text:
A 53-year-old man presents with intermittent abdominal pain for the past 6 months whichhe describes as sharp, mid-abdomen, and relieved with sitting upright. He also describes postprandial bloating and discomfort during these episodes. He has observed that the pain is more noticeable shortly after meals.The patient has frequent large, loose stools that require multiple flushes. He reports a 6.8-kg (15-lb) weight loss over the last 6 months. The patient drinks 4 or 5 bottles of beer daily since the past 10 years. An MRCP is ordered which shows the following-

What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient discussed in this question has chronic pancreatitis. On MRCP, string of pearls sign is appreciated.

Chronic Pancreatitis

  • Has calcifications
  • on MRCP / ERCP
    • Beaded / torturous appearance of pancreatic duct
    • String of pearls / string of beads appearance
    • chain of lake apperance
  • On Barium - Reverse 3 sign of frostberg (also seen in Ca head of pancreas)

questions.text: A newborn is in bad health after an emergency caesarean operation for foetal distress. He has a heart rate of 90 beats per minute. His extremities are blue, while his body is pink. He has some muscular tone and limb flexion. On intense stimulation, he gasps for air irregularly and grimaces. What is the Apgar score of this newborn baby?
questions.solution:
Apgar score

Apgar score is a scoring system used to evaluate a newborn baby. it is done at 1 minute and 5 minutes after birth. it may be repeated at 10 minutes if scores remain low. the Apgar scoreis calculated by adding the total score of 5 components.

score of 0 score of 1 score of 2 component of backronym
skin color blue or pale all over blue at extremities body pink (acrocyanosis) no cyanosis body and extremities pink apperance
pulse rate absent <100 beats / minute > 100 beats / minute pulse
reflex irritability grimace no response to stimulation grimace on suction or aggressive stimulation cry on stimulation, sneezes, coughs grimace
activity flaccid some limb flexion flexed arms and legs that resist extension atcivity
respirtaory effort absent weak, irregular, gasping strong, robust cry respiration

questions.text:
A 30 year old patient presents with diarrhea and multiple episodes of loose stools feels cramps and tiredness. His ECG done shows the following -

What electrolyte abnormality is present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Hypokalemia

  • Death can occur due to respiratory muscle paralysis

causes

  1. Decreased intake
  2. Alkalosis: Potassium shift into cells
  3. sympathomimetic stimulation: Trauma, Thyrotoxic periodic paralysis, Beta2 agonist toxicity (salbutamol)
  4. Renal loss
    • ↑ aldosterone = Conn's sydrome, bilateral adrenal hyperplasia, Ascites, CHF
    • Barter's, Gitelman syndrome
    • salt wasting nephropathy
    • RTA type 1 and 2
  5. Vomiting, diarrhea

C/F:

  1. Cramps /weakness (earliest)
  2. Ileus
  3. Falccid paralysis
  4. hypercapnia: CO2 nacrosis due to diaphragmatic weakness

Work up:

  • serum K+
  • TTKG - Trans tubular K+ gradient
    • if >4 = renal wasting of K+
  • ECG:
    • T wave - absent / inverted
      • T wave inversion causes: Unstable angina NSTEMI hypokalemia

  • ST ↓ segment depression
  • pseudo P- pulmonale
    • p wave >2.5 mm in absence of PAH
  • Prolongation of PR interval
  • Prominent U waves
  • Prolonged QU interval

Complication: Hypo K+ apart from diaphragmatic paralysis

↓

Arrhythmia

↓

Torsades De Pointes

(Hypomagnesemia also causes this)

Rx:

  • if K+ b/w 3.0-3.5 mEq/l - Oral KCL (POTCHLOR)
  • if <3 mEq or can't take orally - I. VKCI (infusion)

Note - for 1 meq/↑ rise in blood: give 200 meq of KCI (slow I.V)

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true about entropion?

Congenital entropion is an uncommon cause; involutional entropion is the most common cause
Snap back test is used for its diagnosis.
It causes eversion of the lid margins
Jones retractor plication is the definitive treatment.
questions.solution:
Entropin

  • Inward rolling of eyelids against the eyeball
  • Inward rolling of eye lashes - Trichiasis

Types

  1. Congenital – very rare à resolves with time
  2. Cicatricial – uncommon
    • Causes trachoma, OCP, post radiotherapy
  3. Involutional – m/c à horizontal lid laxity, disinsertion of lower lid retractors
  4. Spastic – acute ocular irritation

Clinical Features

  • Foreign body sensation
  • Photophobia
  • Blepharospasm
  • Epiphora
  • Redness
  • Discharge

Diagnosis

  • Snap back test – assesses horizontal lid laxity

Treatment

  • Temporary – Lid taping below lower lid
  • Everting sutures – Quickert procedure

  • Jones rectractor plication (definitive treatment)

In ectropion, there is outward rolling of eyelids away from eyeball which causes eversion of the lid margin.

questions.text: A 40-year-old manual labourer appears with a groin swelling. He claims he first observed the appearance today, and that it is accompanied by pain. A lump is discovered right above an medial to the pubic tubercle during examination. The mass is reducible on examination, and there is an impulse while coughing. What is the ONE MOST LIKELY DISEASE?
questions.solution:
The first hint here is his sex (male) and his occupation (manual worker). In adults, male sex and heavy lifting are risk factors for inguinal hernias.

Remember, inguinal hernias has impulse on coughing or bearing down. Femoral hernias are usually irreducible (due to the narrow femoral canal) and cough impulse rarely detectable.

Incarcerated hernia cannot be pushed back into the abdomen by applying manual pressure and hence are irreducible.

Strangulated hernia are also irreducible. They are tense and red and usually followed by symptoms and signs of bowel obstruction.

Discrimination between direct and indirect inguinal hernia by physical examination is not very accurate. In an indirect inguinal hernia, the protrusion passes through the deep inguinal ring and is located lateral to the inferior epigastric artery and direct hernias through the posterior wall of the inguinal canal.

questions.text: After playing football, a 29-year-old man acquired a red, raised rash on his trunk. Over the last few hours, the rash has been very itchy and has now spread to his arms. His medical history includes asthma, which he was diagnosed with at the age of seven. What is the ONE MOST APPROPRIATE management technique?
questions.solution:
• This man is suffering from urticaria. Oral antihistamines would be indicated.
  • Since this is an allergic reaction, the only two reasonable options are A and C in this question. However, in the context of allergic reactions, IM adrenaline should only be used in anaphylactic shock whereby the patient would have breathing difficulties.
  • The followings are the indications of adrenaline in anaphylaxis:
    • Hoarseness of voice
    • Wheeze
    • Shortness of breath
    • Shock
    • Stridor
    • Swelling of the tongue and cheek
    • Facial swelling
  • If you see an urticaria like allergic reaction, with none of the following indications stated above for adrenaline, then pick the oral antihistamine as the answer.

URTICARIA

  • The typical lesion is a central itchy white papule or plaque due to swelling of the surface of the skin (wheals). This is surrounded by an erythematous flare. The lesions are variable in size and shape and may be associated with swelling of the soft tissues of the eyelids, lips and tongue (angioedema).
  • Individual lesions are typically transient. They come and go within a few minutes to hours.
  • Acute urticaria is defined as urticaria present for less than 6 weeks
  • Chronic urticaria is when urticaria persist beyond 6 weeks
  • Remember that urticarial rashes tend to last less than 24 hours.

Management

  • Where possible, identify and treat the cause. Nonspecific aggravating factors should be minimised, such as overheating, stress, alcohol, and caffeine
  • Antihistamines:
    • Non-sedating H1 antihistamines are the mainstay of treatment.
    • In pregnancy chlorphenamine is often the first choice of antihistamine.

questions.text: On defecation, a 25-year-old lady with long-term constipation experiences significant anorectal pain. Blood streaks cover her faeces, which she notices. Because she is in so much pain, a rectal examination is impossible. She recalls that the symptoms began after an episode of sudden, intense pain when defecating. What is the ONE MOST LIKELY DISEASE?
questions.solution:
Anal fissures are caused by constipation and straining. Patients often remember the episode of pain when the tear occurred. The pain is so severe tht they would refuse rectal examinations.

The distractor here is anal abscesses and haemorrhoids. Anal abscesses present with painful swelling and defecation can be painful however blood is not typical. Haemorrhoids may also present similarly with pain and bleeding (like anal fissures) however the symptoms of pain are usually intermittent (unless thrombosed where the pain is acutely severe) and do not tend to appear as streaks of blood on stools.

Fissure-in-Ano

Location of dentate line - usually 2cm below the anal verge.

Longitudinal split in the anoderm from anal verge to the dentate line

Location – In posterior midline at 6’o clock position

Fissure is of two types

  • Acute fissure

  • Chronic fissures

Chronic fissures - Characterized by Triad

  • CANOE- SHAPED ULCER
  • SENTINEL PILE (aka skin tag)
  • Hypertrophied papilla

Pathophysiology

  • Spasm of Internal Anal sphincter
  • Patients have constipation
  • During excessive straining at the time of defecation, the fecal matter passing through internal anal sphincter injures the pain sensitive mucosa of anal canal.

Tear/ split in the anoderm

↓

Decreased vascularity

↓

Healing of Tear decreases (due to ischemia)

  • Principle of treatment is based on relaxing the spasm
  • Fissure in Ano is similar to Achalasia cardia

Clinical features

  • Serve pain during defecation
  • Streaking of blood over stool
  • In fissure in Ano - Digital rectal examination is contraindicated.
  • Examine the gluteal region, find the longitudinal spilt in posterior midline

Management

  • Initially conservative management
    • Sitz bath
    • Stool softener
  • Medical Treatment
  • CCB – 2% Diltiazem Gel – (Local application)
  • Nitrates - 0.2% nitroglycerine
  • Botox injection into sphincters
  • Lord’s procedure – manual dilatation of sphincter (not performed usually).
  • TOC - NOTARA’S lateral sphincterotomy (divide internal anal sphincter laterally)
  • Anal advancement flap

questions.text: Which statement is NOT true about osteosarcoma?

choices.text: It is an osteoid forming bone tumor
Pagetoid type has the worst prognosis
Methotrexate is used in the treatment of osteosarcoma

questions.solution:
Osteosarcoma - Cancer oc the Young

  • 2nd decade
  • In metaphysic
  • Radiation induced sarcoma (aster 10-15 year a Radiotherapy)
  • Radio-resistant bone tumor
  • Osteoid (Matrix) corming bone tumor
  • "Bone Corming bone tumor"
  • OS & soft tissue sarcomas ore associated with germlineretinoblastoma
  • Most Common site —Lower end a femur
  • Has homogenous unicormcalcicication
  • Positive Codman's triangle (wide area a activity)
  • (Knee-skeletal maturity 18 years) Patient's age-19 years {2nd decade}
  • Metaphysis in lower end occemur
  • <1% Paget's (osteits decormans) OS

Clinical features

  • pain / Night pain

Types

  1. Classical - intramedullary /intra-osseous
  2. Periosteal - Arise from cambium layer
  3. Paraosteal - Posterior aspect of lower femur - Good Prognosis
  4. Pagetoid - AKA Osteitiside for mans - Worse prognosis
  5. Radiation Induced (10-15 years after radiotherapy)

Treatment

T- 10 protocol → used for OS

  • Methotrexate - very important drug (Etoposide not used)
  • Chemotherapy → Tumor shrinks → Excision (calculate the %)
    • >95% necrosis → CHemosensitive tumor
      • same chemotherapy is given post -op
    • <95% necrosis → chemo-resistant
      • ↓post op

new chemotherapy combination

  • T-10 protocol → 70% 5 years survival

Prognosis

  • Poor prognosis
  • Depend on:
  • extent of disease (stage) - most important
  • Grade of lesion
  • most common site of metastasis → lungs (poor prognosis)
  • systemic metastasis > Pulmonary metastasis

OS is malignancy causing pneumothorax

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman has intermittent dizziness, weakness, and unsteady gait for the last several weeks. She complains of visual loss and pain in the right eye that worsens with eye movement for the past 2 days. On neurologic examination, her right eye has diminished visual acuity and an afferent pupillary defect. Both lower extremities have spastic paresis, hyperreflexia, and positive Babinski sign. Which is the most appropriate test to confirm the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient likely has presented with multiple sclerosis

Features

  1. Autoimmune medicated
  2. More common in females than male
  3. Environmental risk factor - Vitamin -D deficiency
  4. More common in North America (sunlight exposure is lesser - disease is more common, probably vitamin - D play role in immunodulation)

Clinical features

(usually young females of Caucasian / North American descent)

Prevalence - sensory symptoms > optic neuritis

  1. Sensory symptoms (37%)
    • Paraesthesia
    • Pin and needle sensation
    • sensory level present + Torso (spinal cord involvement)
    • pain multifocal
  2. Optic neuritis (36%)
    • ↓se in visual acuity U/I > B/L
    • decrease in colors perception (desaturation)
    • Fundus normal or papillitis
    • visual loss U/L > B/L
    • periorbital pain ↑se on movement
    • internuclear ophthalmoplegia
      • lesion of medial longitudinal fasciculus that result in impaired adduction of one particular eye and contralateral eye will move normally in patient.
  3. Spastic weakness with features of UMNL, patients may perceive spasticity as muscle cramps.
  4. facial nerve palsy
    • due to lesion of nucleus of 7th nerve in pons
    • taste sensation preserved
  5. ataxia
    • Gait ataxia : Paleocerebellum (GP)
    • Truncal ataxia : Archicerebellum
    • scanning speech
  6. vertigo / deafness - 8th nerve
  7. Trigeminal neuralgia - 5th nerve
  8. Glossopharyngeal neuralagia - pain on swallowing
  9. Ancillary symptoms
  10. Detrusor hyperreflexia

  • Detrusor hyperreflexia - In CNS lesion there is loss of inhibitory control causing urine incontinence nocturnal) enuresis.

Work up

1. In gadolinium enhanced MRI = Plaques / Dawson fingers

↓

I.O.C

↓

Periventricular (white matter area) / juxtacortical or infratentorial (cerebellum)

  • FLAIR - FLuid attenuated inversion recovery: suppress signal of CSF, periventricular lesion will stand up relatively better

2. Visual evoke potential (VEP) = Plaque formation is smaller in size, voltage generated decreased leading to ↑ Latency period.

3. CSF = mild to moderate pleocytosis proteins slightly increase

4. CSF electrophoresis

↓

Oligoclonal bands in CSF

Treatment

  • Acute attack of optic neuritis = IV methylprednisone

Disease modifying drugs (to prevent disease)

  1. β interferon
  2. Glatiramer (immunomodulartory) = Glutamic acid, lysine, alanine, tyrosine
  3. Oral fingolimod
  4. Oral dimethyl fumarate (DMF)
  5. Natalizumab = once a month infusion

↓

inhibit binding of T lymphocytes to capillaries related to blood brain barrier

↓

Damage to BBB is minimized

S/E

  • JC virus activation leading to progressive multifocal leukoencephalopthy
  • JC virus negative patients are eligible to get infusion of natalizumab.

6. Ocrelizumb = acts by attacking mature B cell which express CD 20. It is used for allowed for management of P.P.M.S

questions.text: A 34-year-old patient was taken to the hospital with acute depression and suicidal ideation. He sought to take his own life. He had been on sertraline for a year and had only stopped taking it a month ago. He had been admitted to the mental unit for mania two years before. The patient wants to know if he can be started on a long-term medicine to help him with his symptoms after he is discharged. What SINGLE drug will be the most effective for his condition?
questions.solution:
• The patient is suffering from bipolar disorder. Long-term management requires mood stabilisers and therefore lithium is the best option.
  • Bipolar affective disorder (commonly known as manic depression) Classically, periods of prolonged and profound depression alternate with periods of excessively elevated and irritable mood, known as mania.
  • Most people who battle with the effects of the disorder would rather live a normal life, free from the unpredictability of mood swings, which most of us take for granted.

The symptoms of mania characteristically include:

  • Decreased need for sleep
  • Pressured speech
  • Increased libido
  • Reckless behaviour without regard for consequences
  • Grandiosity
  • More talkative than usual

These symptoms of mania would alternate with depression

  • Treatment
    • Mood stabilizers (Lithium)- Despite problems with tolerability, lithium still remainsthe gold standard in the treatment of bipolar affective disorder

questions.text: A 25 year old man falls over his flexed wrist. Which type of fracture would be most expected in this case?
questions.solution:
Smith’s fracture is expected when a person falls over his flexed wrist

Smith's fracture (Reverse Colle's)

  • Fracture of distal radius in which the distal fracture fragment is displaced volarly (ventrally)
  • Mech of injury - fall on outstretched hand

Treatment:

  • Supination + lateral displacement + Impacted bones + Posterior displacement

questions.text: During thyroid surgery, a 31-year-old lady has a damage to the right external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve. What is this patient's SINGLE most likely symptom?
questions.solution:
The two most important complications of nerve damages you would need to know during a thyroidectomy is:

  1. Recurrent laryngeal nerve damage
  2. Superior laryngeal nerve damage

A unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve damage damage results in hoarseness and for bilateral damage symptoms include aphonia and airway obstruction.

The external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve is one of the nerves commonly injured in thyroid surgery. Injury to this nerve results in the inability to lengthen a vocal fold and, thus, inability to create a high-pitched sound (dysphonia). They would have a mono toned voice. This would be detrimental to a person who is a professional singer. So in this stem, injury to the external branch of superior laryngeal nerve is likely to produce symptoms of dysphonia.

Complications of thyroidectomy

  • Nerve Injuries
    • MC injured nerve - external branch of superior laryngeal nerve (aka external laryngeal nerve) due to its proximity to superior thyroid artery.
    • leads to loss of tension in the vocal cord with diminished power and range in the voice
    • recurrent laryngeal nerve - may be unilateral or bilateral, transient or permanent
    • cervical sympathetic trunk
  • haemorrhage
    • it is the most frequent life threatening complications of thyroidectomy
    • most often develops within 24 hours
    • arterial bleed - central compartment pressure exceeds venous pressure - venous edema of larynx - airway obstruction
    • immediate release of sutures and evaculating the hematoma and wound exploration to be done
  • respiratory obstruction
    • mc cause - laryngeal edema (due to intubation injury)
    • other casues - RLN palsy, Tension hematoma
  • parathyroid insufficiency
    • mc cause - vascular infarction of parathyroid gland (if inferior thyroid artery is ligated away from parathyroid gland during surgery)
    • parathyroid insufficiency most commonly presents on 2nd - 5thd ay of surgery
    • manifestations are carpopedal spasm, tingling, numbness over perioral region
    • treatment
      • mild to moderate symptoms (calcium level >8 gm/dl): oral calcium supplementation
      • severe symptoms (<8gm/dl): IV calcium gluconate
  • thyroid insufficiency
  • thyrotoxic crisis (storm)
    • mc cause - inadequate preoperative preparation of a thyrotoxic patient
    • acute exacerbation of hyperthyroidism
  • wound ifnection
  • hypertrophic or keloid scar

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT an indication for penetrating keratoplasty?

choices.text: Opacification of the superficial one-third of the corneal stroma not by a potentially recurrent disease.

questions.solution:
Keratoplasty

Penetrating Keratoplasty (PK) Lamellar Keratoplasty (LK)

Full thickness keratoplasty

All 5 layers taken from donor

Corneal transplant is the most successful organ transplant in the body [cornea is avascular]

  • LK is more successful than PK
  • Max. rejection is from endothelium
  • LK is technically more demanding

Partial thickness keratoplasty

Only outer layers taken from donor recipient retains his own

Endothelium

Descemet's membrane

Stroma ±

Donor provides

Epithelium

Bowman's membrane

Stroma ±

Indications

PK [penetractingKeratoplasty]

  1. Pseudophakic bullous keratopathy [PBK] [mc - worldwide]
  2. Fuchs Endothelial Dystrophy (FED)
  3. Non healing ulcer
  4. Corneal scar [mc indication in India]
  5. Corneal dystrophy
  6. Keratoconus [mc indication in America]
  7. Chemical injuries

Superficial lamellar keratoplasty

This involves partial-thickness excision of the corneal epithelium and stroma so that the endothelium and part of the deep stroma are left behind as a bed for appropriately partial-thickness donor cornea. The area grafted depends on the extent of the disease process to be addressed.

  • Indications
    • Opacification of the superficial one-third of the corneal stroma not caused by potentially recurrent disease.
    • Marginal corneal thinning or infiltration as in recurrent pterygium, Terrien marginal degeneration, and limbal dermoids or other tumours.
    • Localized thinning or descemetocoele formation

questions.text: Which of the following statement is incorrect regarding Budd-Chiari syndrome?

choices.text: Myeloproliferative disorder can cause Budd-Chiari syndrome
Classical triad includes- Abdominal pain, jaundice, hepatomegaly

questions.solution:
BUDD-CHIARI SYNDROME

  • TRIAD- Ascites + Hepatomegaly + Abdominal pain
  • Affects young females
  • Hepatic venous obstruction due to thrombus -> acutely congested liver -> impaired liver function and portal hypertension
  • Acute thrombus - fulminant hepatic failure
  • Chronic - cirrhosis
  • Cause - myeloproliferative disorder or procoagulant state such as antithrombin3, protein C or protein S deficiency
  • Gross enlargement of the caudate lobe due to preserved direct venous drainage to the IVC noted
  • Treatment
    • Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt
    • Liver transplantation
    • Retrohepatic expandable metallic stent

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding nuclear medicine are correct?

Tc99m- pertechnetate is used in diagnosis of Meckel’s Diverticulum.
MUGA scan can be used to evaluate ejection fraction of the heart.
Super scan is seen with diffuse metastatic bone disease.
I124 is a positron emitter and used in PET scan
questions.solution:
Tc99m - Pertechnetate

Uses:

  • Thyroid scintigraphy
  • Salivary scintigraphy
  • Meckel's diverticulum

MUGA scan (Multi-gated acquisition scan)

  • Tc 99m labeled RBC is used
  • Evaluate ventricular function / ejection fraction - cardiac ventriculography (but most accurate investigation for ventricular function is contrast - MRI)

Super scan

  • It resembles normal bone scan but kidney is not visualized
  • it is seen with:
    • renal failure
    • diffuse metastatic bone disease
    • diffuse metabolic

Different types of radioactive iodine

  • Normal iodine is l127
Radioisotope t1/2 uses
l131 8 days

Used for radio ablation; systemic radiotherapy for well

Differentiated thyroid metastasis; emits β & γ ray killing of Ca cells is done by β rays
l125 60 days

Brachytherapy for prostate tumor, radio immunoassay
l124 4 days

it is a position emitter used in PET scan
l123 13 hrs

RAIU studies /scintigraphy; functional scan (pertechnetate scan can be used)

questions.text: A 33-year-old lady claims that she wakes up in the middle of the night to use the restroom. She wets herself most of the time because she does not make it to the toilet in time. What is the ONE MOST LIKELY DISEASE?
questions.solution:
• Urge incontinence / overactive bladder (OAB) → is due to detrusor over activity. Common complaint is “when I have to go to the toilet, I really have to go” or “I have the desire to pass urine and sometimes urine leaks before I have time to get to the toilet”
  • Stress incontinence → leaking small amounts of urine when coughing or laughing. Usually with a history of many vaginal deliveries as this would weaken the pelvic floor muscles.
  • Mixed incontinence → a mix of both urge and stress incontinence
  • Overflow incontinence → involuntary release of urine from an overfull urinary bladder, often in the absence of any urge to urinate. Occurs in people who have a blockage of the bladder outlet (benign prostatic hyperplasia, prostate cancer, or narrowing of the urethra), or when the muscle that expels urine from the bladder is too weak to empty the bladder normally.
  • Urethrovaginal fistula → Opening between vagina and urethra. Common complaint is“ there is continual leakage of urine from my vagina” or “my vagina has a foul smell”

MANAGEMENT OF URINARY INCONTINENCE

The management of incontinence depends on whether urge or stress urinary incontinence is predominant.

  • For stress incontinence:
    • Pelvic floor exercise is the initial treatment of choice. At least eight contractions are performed three times a day for a minimum of three months.
    • Surgical procedures e.g., retropubic mid-urethral tape procedures may be required.
    • Duloxetine is used for those who are not surgical candidates.
  • For urge incontinence
    • Bladder retraining (minimum of six weeks). The idea is to gradually increase the intervals between voiding
    • Bladder stabilising drugs: antimuscarinic agents are first-line( oxybutynin, tolterodine or darifenacin). Immediate release oxybutynin should, however, be avoided in frail older women.

questions.text: 5 days ago, a 44-year-old woman underwent a thorough abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral salpingooophorectomy. She is now experiencing significant stomach discomfort and bloating. She was advised to drink plenty of water, but she is still unable to pass gas. There are no bowel sounds heard. What is the ONE MOST SUITABLE NEXT STEP?
questions.solution:
• The likely diagnosis here is paralytic ileus and an x-ray can help with diagnosis.
  • Prolonged surgery is one of the major causes of paralytic ileus and it occurs due to overhandling of the bowel.
  • Paralytic ileus is to be expected in the first few days after abdominal surgery. Bowel sounds are absent and there is no passage of gas. There may be mild distension, but there is usually minimal pain.

X-ray findings of Paralytic ileus :

  • Gasless abdomen
  • Ground Glass appearance
  • Sentinel loop
  • Colon cut-off sign

Paralytic Ileus

  • failure of transmission of peristaltic waves due to neuromuscular failure (myenteric plexus) and submucous (meissner's plexus)
  • the resultant stasis leads to accumulation of fluid and gas within the bowel with associated distention, vomiting, absence of bowel sounds and absolute constipation

Etiology:

  • Abdominal Surgery
  • Intra-abdominal infection
  • Dyselectrolytemia
  • Drugs

Clinical Presentation

  • Abdominal distension
  • Vomiting
  • Dilated bowel loops
  • No mechanical obstructiion
  • Colicky pain is not a feature
Paralytic Ileus Mechanical Obstruction
  • Pain is not a feature of paralytic ileus and if present a steady, diffuse discomfort
  • bowel sounds are hypoactive or absent
  • presence of gas in colon & rectum in paralytic ileus on abdominal x- ray
  • pain is colicky in mechanical obstruction
  • Hyperactive bowel sounds in mechanical obstruction
  • absence of gas in colon & rectum in mechanical (complete)

Treatment

  • Pass an NGT to empty the stomach of fluid and gas if the patient is nauseatedor vomiting. Small volumes of tolerated oral intake may help mild ileus toresolve.
  • Ensure adequate hydration by IV infusion (‘drip and suck’).
  • Reduce opiate analgesia and encourage the patient to mobilize

questions.text: All are true for rhinophyma except-

choices.text: Seen in long standing cases of acne rosacea
Most common in men in middle age
It is due to hypertrophy of sebaceous glands of skin
It is associated with diabetes mellitus

questions.solution: Rhinophyma or potato tumor is a slow-growing benign tumor due to hypertrophy of the sebaceous glands of the tip of nose often seen in cases of long-standing acne rosa- cea. It presents as a pink, lobulated mass over the nose with superficial vascular dilation; mostly affects men past middle age. Patient seeks advice because of the unsightly appearance of the tumor, or obstruction to breathing and vision due to large size of the tumor. Treatment consists of paring down the bulk of tumor with sharp knife or carbon dioxide laser and the area allowed to re-epithelialize. Sometimes, tumor is completely excised and the raw area skin grafted.

questions.solution:
PSEUDO HYPOPARATHYROIDISM:

  • PTH values: ↑↑
  • Receptors: Resistance to PTH, because of detect in GNAS gene

C/F:

  • Similar to Hypoparathyroidism/ Rickets like illness.
  • Make a fist of the patient and compare with your own fist. Patient will be having short 4th and 5th metacarpal bones leading to Knuckle-Knuckle- dimple-dimple sign/ Archibald sign.
  • Rickets like illness + archibald sign , Albright Hereditary Osteodystrophy.(AHO)

INVESTIGATIONS: 1.

  1. Calcium - ↓
  2. Po4- ↑
  3. SAP - Normal

Note:

4 Pseudo-hypoparathyroidism is differentiated from Hypoparathyroidism based on the levels of PTH

  • PTH ↑ in pseudo-hypoparathyroidism and reduced in hypoparathyroidism:

MANAGEMENT:

No definite treatment possible due to defect in receptor

questions.text: A patient complains of difficulty eating a large meal three months after recovering from an operation to cure peptic ulcer disease. A chicken scinitgraphy test using 99m Tc confirms a significant delay in stomach emptying. a delay in gastric emptying may be due to which of the following?
questions.solution: Gastric emptying is slowed after truncal land selective vagomoty. A drainage treatment is required if a vagotomy (truncal or selective) is performed (eg. pyloroplasty). A mechanical gastric outlet obstruction, diabetes, myxedema, hypokalemia, or the administration of anti-cholinergic or opiate medicines might cause a change in gastric motility with a delay in gastric emptying. With ZES, retained gastric antrum syndrome, steatorrhea, or major small-bowel resection, where the ability to decrease stomach acid output is reduced, rapid gastric emptying might occur. Increased motility and emptying of the stomach come from the failure of the switch-off mechanism that inhibits acid secretion.

questions.text: A 68 year old man presents with exertional chest pain and progressive difficulty in breathing with activity. On examination, he has a slow rise pulse with a delayed peak and a crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur. His echo shows an aortic valve size of 0.7 cm2. What is the best treatment option for this patient?

choices.text: Use beta blockers and ACE inhibitors only

questions.solution:
In aortic stenosis damage of valves can be due to various causes such as senile calcification scarring due to RHD. In old age, degenerative calcification associated with atherosclerosis leads to the involvement of abdominal aorta/root of aorta and the area around the aortic valve causing fibro calcification of aortic valve. Balloon dilatation & balloon valvoplasty is contraindicated in these patients with calcified valves as balloon dilatation would lead the calcified valve cusps to break into small fragments that may get lodged into brain resulting in development of stroke in the patients.

In severe AS

  • Aortic valve area <1 cm2 (0.6 cm2/m2 BSA surface area)
    • left ventricle has very high pressure. When the blood from LV passes via stenosis aortic valve, there is very much increased turbulence in blood flow.
    • volume of blood going from LV to aorta is decerased but velocity of blood flow is increased

Stages of AS

Stage A

  • risk factors present
  • no narrowing of valve

Stage B

  • progressive narrowing of valve - (i.e mild to moderate aortic stenosis)

Stage C

  • severe aortic stenosis but patients is asymptomatic

Stage D

  • severe aortic stenosis & patient is symptomatic

Severe aortic stenosis

Definition:

  1. Transvalvular pressure gradient of >40 mmHg
    • Transvalvular pressure gradient (ΔP) = LV - Aorta
      • pressure difference b/w left ventricle & aorta
  2. Ejection velocity - >4m/sec [i.e. 4 times of normal]
    • [Normal ejection velocity - 1m/sec]
  3. size of orifice - <1cm2/<0.6cm2/m2 BSA
    • (BSA - body surface area) any of these 3 - terminology written in MCQ means severe aortic stenosis

Treatment

for stage D - transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR)

for stage C

  • if patient has concomitant risk factors like
    • concomitant triple vessel disease (TVD)
    • left ventricle ejection fraction <50%
  • in these conditions, treatment is again tran catheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR)
    • statins are given to prevent further progression of atherosclerosis & thus triple vessel disease
    • statins doesn't prevent further progression of calcification
